That was a measure, I think, of the enormous depth of feeling that there is in the community amongst parents—non-custodial particularly but also custodial—who have to deal with the Child Support Agency.

The policy we took to the election did not deal with all the issues. It dealt with the joint select committee headed by the honourable member for Chifley (Mr Price) in the last parliament. It made some specific suggestions about administrative changes and about policy development. Some of those have been picked up in the bill that we are dealing with today, the Child Support Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 1) 1996.

I think every member of parliament can, as the member for Barton (Mr McClelland) has done in his last speech, tell horrific stories about how custodial and non‐custodial parents have come up against the Child Support Agency and found it a very difficult process. Over the last six or seven years I think that has dramatically improved. Certainly, in the early part of the last parliament one could be forgiven for thinking that there was going to be a revolution in some of these areas where people who had to deal with the Child Support Agency saw their lifeblood being drained away from them by what they thought were very unfair administrative and policy practices required by the legislation.

The danger in this area is always, of course, to build expectations. I think that both the former Labor government and the present coalition government have been wary of building expectations. Governments are expected by both the custodial parent and the non‐custodial parent simply to come up with the solutions, and the protagonists in the debate have very different solutions to the problems. So government has to be very careful not to build up the expectations of people who are, at the very least, on the edge of collapse over the Child Support Agency. In many cases, they have collapsed. I think that the suicide rate amongst non‐custodial parents is far above the average for the community. This is a very delicate area and if governments are not careful, if they build up expectations unrealistically, they can do more damage than good.

I welcome this bill because, in a very small way to start with, it is attempting to address some of the administrative and policy problems in the program. Down the track we can further develop, review and improve to the point where the Child Support Agency is achieving its goals. While this area will always be fraught with problems, we can always improve it administratively; we can improve it in its operation; and we can also improve it in principle. In the last parliament, the member for Chifley (Mr Price) headed up the Joint Select Committee on Certain Family Law Issues which dealt with the Child Support Agency and he came down with an extraordinarily comprehensive report.

At the time it broke the record for the number of submissions received by a joint select committee or a standing committee on any issue that was being investigated. I think that there was a media report at the time about the jamming of phones and people unable to get through to deliver their verdict on the Child Support Agency. He did a very good job with his committee—that has been said by other speakers in this debate and I am sure will be said throughout the debate. The bill is a step in the right direction. I would now wish to turn to some of the specifics of the bill. While few have argued about the concept of the Child Support Agency and that it is the responsibility of parents rather than the taxpayer to raise children, several problems have arisen since the agency's establishment. Burdens have been unfairly placed on both custodial and non-custodial parents, as well as those employing the latter.

This Child Support Legislation Amendment Bill will remedy some of these inequities. One of the major problems encountered by many people in their dealings with government departments is the inability to accurately assess, and more pointedly, predict income. The Child Support Agency calculates income and thus the level of payments by taking into account the tax returns of two prior years. But so often circumstances change and overpayments are made to custodial parents. The current arrangement is for these custodial parents to repay the excess sum which can pose quite a problem if the money has already been spent. My officers spend a lot of time dealing with constituents who receive notice from one government department or another that they owe money. Whether the overpayment is the result of wilful or unwitting error by the constituent or a mistake has been made somewhere in the department, there can be some deal of stress associated with the demand to repay.

With the Child Support Agency at least, there will be no repayments as such, rather the liability of the non-custodial parent will be annualised and regular payments reduced to cover the initial overpayment. This is a sensible solution given the ever changing circumstances of people. This initiative will also apply to underpayments where the shortfall will be made up over the course of the year. This does not mean that a non-custodial parent can make a short payment and have the remainder annualised, but if the assessed payment is found to be inadequate according to the formula, that difference can be made up over the year.

These measures will reduce the unnecessary flow of money where a non-custodial parent overpays, the custodial parent repays and then receives some, if not all, of that money back in due course. There will be less time-wasting administrative chores for the Child Support Agency. At the same time the non-custodial parents will pay and the custodial parents receive the correct amount based on the formula. This bill signals the intent of the government to ease the burden on employers by increasing the possibilities for alternative collection methods. While collection of payments by means of payroll deduction has been certainly effective in many instances, it is worth while to ask why employers should be involved in this scheme at all other than for the obvious reason that they certainly have first and best access to the salary of the non-custodial parent.

Certainly there are questions of privacy involved and the provisions enabling non-custodial parents to deal directly with the agency, rather than through their employer, are welcomed. This legislation will enable those parents who pay in a timely fashion to make direct payments, as long as they remain timely. It should not be necessary for an employer to know the details of an employee's financial arrangements. In the future they will be left out of the loop if the registrar decides that an employee is up to date with regular payments.

This government is intent on reducing the impositions on business and it is to be hoped that this move benefits many employers. In these provisions the requirement for employers to maintain records of CSA reductions has been reduced from seven years to five. That is some consolation also, but it seems we are still asking people to maintain financial records for periods far exceeding those required by other western nations.

The third main provision of this bill is to establish procedures to enable fairer property divisions between couples who are splitting up. The Family Court may consider future incomings, such as superannuation, when it rules on cases, but at present it has no way of assessing child support that has not been previously claimed. The new clause allows consideration of child support for which a non-custodial parent might at some in the future be held liable. That consideration can include potential private arrangements as well as Child Support Agency assessments.

The fact that we are dealing with this bill in the Main Committee in no way diminishes its importance. Rather, it indicates that there is agreement across the political spectrum, which is testimony to the need for changes to the operations of the agency. That has been noted in the speech by the member for Barton (Mr McClelland) and by me, and I am sure it will be followed up by other speakers in this debate.

During the last parliament, as I have said, I assisted the then shadow minister for social security on this area. One of the chief responsibilities in that role was to review the structures of the Child Support Agency. At the same time, the joint select committee was doing the same thing and so was the Commonwealth Ombudsman. In 1995, the number of complaints to the Commonwealth Ombudsman about the Child Support Agency was approaching 2,400. In fact, the Ombudsman reports that, since 1991, she has received more complaints about the CSA than about any other Commonwealth department or agency.

BREAK.PARA: I am sure that the changes will not soothe every frayed temper. But they are the beginning of reform to a much maligned, albeit most necessary and worthwhile body, which serves about 33 per cent of all separated or divorced couples.

TALK.START.PARA: —Before calling the member for Kalgoorlie, it is my understanding that all members have different requirements from time to time and previous engagements that may require them to wear casual dress. But the standard of dress needs to be maintained in the chamber and that is for the individual member to consider.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Campbell, Graeme, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —Thank you for your sartorial advice, Mr Deputy Speaker. I think the standing orders have already substantiated that I am perfectly attired for the chamber. There are many precedents.

SPEECH.PARA: Like so much legislation, the Child Support Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 1) 1996 really does not get to the nub of what needs to be done. It is quite clear that we should be sweeping away the Family Court in its entirety and returning this sort of legislation to the district and supreme courts. The Family Court is a giant, self‐serving empire, it is very expensive and it is the source of a lot of the angst which is subsequently reflected in the Child Support Agency.

Apart from the administrative changes, there are three amendments here that I think are worth while. If a high assessment has been made by the CSA and, some time after, the non‐custodial parent applies successfully to amend its assessment, this causes an overpayment to the custodial parent. In the past, the custodial parent had to pay this money back. Instead, it will now be calculated within the future maintenance payments, reducing that amount rather than causing the custodial parent the often difficult task of paying back the money.

An amendment will allow the non‐custodial parents to elect to make direct payments to the CSA, rather than having them deducted from their wages by their employer. This has been a source of embarrassment to many people, and I am sure it is a responsibility that the employer does not want. This is a good amendment. But in reality, if the custodial parent does not agree to this method, or in the event that the non‐custodial parent defaults even once, they will have no choice but to be placed back into the wage deduction system with little or no chance of opting out again in the future.

The amendment should have been made long ago whereby prospective future maintenance, even though it has not been assessed, may be considered in the Family Court proceedings when calculating property and spousal maintenance. At least now the Family Court can recognise that the non‐custodial parent will have the future child support liabilities outside the court jurisdiction.

There were about 163 recommendations put forward by the committee. Not many of them have been acted on. In some cases I think that is a good thing as they would have been a further burden on the non‐custodial parent. With regard to lowering the percentage for the assessment based on gross wages, the percentage deductions are far too high and do not take into account the different levels of living costs around Australia. This is particularly true in an electorate like mine where living costs in some country areas are extremely high.

Raising exempted income for non‐custodial parents with dependents in new relationships is something which should be looked at. It is almost impossible for non‐custodial parents to start a new family because of their maintenance commitments. We should also not forget that they will be trying to purchase another home after the divorce settlement. I know many cases where people in very good employment have actually taken recourse to going on the dole rather than meet payments which make life simply impossible for them. Of course, there is no sense in that, either for the non‐custodial parent or the nation.

Using a sliding scale for maintenance liability based on a child's age—as it is obvious that a younger child costs far less to keep than a teenager—is something that we should be looking at. In many cases now, the custodial parent gets a set amount which, clearly, is not being expended on the child in the early years and, in very few cases, I fear, is it being set aside for the education of that child, or to cover the costs incurred by that child at a later stage. It seems to me to be far more sensible to adjust the payments so that there is a sliding scale so that when the need is greater, greater payments are made. The non‐custodial parent can then feel that the money he or she is paying is actually going to the welfare of the child. I find that one of the great sources of angst amongst non‐custodial parents is that they feel that the money they are paying is not going to the maintenance of the child.

Allowing for more substantiated, more in kind payments in lieu of cash—I think that they would have to be substantiated—would also remove much of the hopeless anger and frustration non‐custodial parents feel when they know that their money is not being used in the direct care of their child. This system would be more manageable than trying to have the custodial parent account for expenditure. It would be simply impossible to get the custodial parent to account for expenditure. You would have to say who would assess it and that, of course, raises a whole new source of trouble when you are getting some of these welfare agencies to do the assessment.

The custodial parent's allowable income of approximately $36,130 before maintenance payments are deducted should also be lowered depending on how many dependents that person has. It seems to be an absolute nonsense that a custodial parent earning that income and having one child has to make no commitment at all to the child's maintenance, while often the spouse is earning very little more. Both parents have a responsibility, as they should. That is quite clear, and that needs to be looked at. Quite frankly, I cannot see why this is not done.

I know of many cases where the angst in the relationship is caused by lack of access. The custodial parent will move away and the non‐custodial parent is often put in a position where he or she—usually he—simply cannot afford the high cost of travel to get access to the child. This, too, needs to be factored in when looking at payments.

A previous year's assessment that has been found to be too high based on income statements should be processed by the CSA and then the current monthly liability should be adjusted accordingly. Currently, any previous year's variation of assessment can only be handled by the child support review officer, which is a very long process. I understand that such review applications take at least six months to be processed, leaving the non‐custodial parents in the position where they have to pay the current assessments until such time as the review is concluded.

I think that the Price report did a good job. I believe that we should be looking more closely at that report and doing more in this regard. One has to say, at least, that the government has acted in some degree. The actions in my view do not go far enough and they do not address the real causes of angst that exist in this legislation. Until we get rid of some of the anomalies, until we do give parents a greater say in the self‐management of their children's welfare, I think that we are going to have ongoing trouble. I just hope that this legislation is not taken by the government to be the end of the process. I hope that they will keep in mind the need for ongoing amendments and see that they are introduced into the House.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: West, Andrea, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —One of the greatest problems encountered by me as both a candidate and as an elected representative for Bowman over the past 14 months has been the difficulties constituents have brought to me concerning their dealings with the Child Support Agency. Never have I seen such heartache and anxiety being caused by one government funded agency. Over the past 14 months my office has received a continuous stream of devastated parents both custodial and non‐custodial seeking major changes to the current situation they find themselves in as a result of their dealings with both the Family Court and the Child Support Agency.

SPEECH.PARA: When you look at the speakers list for this issue, you can see the length and breadth and depth of the issue and how it impacts across Australia in as many electorates as we have represented here in the national capital.

When a relationship is ended through divorce, the parents leave the court one day and life ceases to be the same again. They then enter the nightmarish world of dealing with the Child Support Agency. Over the past 12 months, I believe the agency has made some minor changes to administration. Members have been briefed on the administration and how the bureaucrats deal with cases and clients. I have been briefed by public servants on what they do and how they do it. I still get a constant stream of parents coming through my door suffering from the administrative failures and the consequences of dealing the Child Support Agency.

I can understand the problems the public servants have in this day-to-day running of the agency. They are dealing, day after day, hour by hour, with problems dealing with relationship breakdown. I can understand how the parents feel dealing with an agency day to day when no change seems imminent or is in any way in the future going to improve their situation.

This child support legislation has three main points. The use of election where income has changed will avoid the need for people in receipt of payments to repay any excess monies that they have been paid. Under the current legislation, if someone is overpaid in child support, they have been forced to repay that money. This can cause considerable strain on the finances, usually with two families trying to support another family. Overpayments occur when the payer's income drops and their payments are reassessed. If the reassessment shows they have been paying too much, they are usually refunded the amount. What the new legislation proposes is that the overpayments will be taken into account when future payments are calculated. The new calculations will also better reflect the paying parent's capacity to pay.

The second point is electing for employer withholding not to apply. This section gives the paying parent a choice of how they pay their child support—a more flexible arrangement. A paying parent may elect to pay the money to the Child Support Registrar rather than have it automatically deducted from their pay. It will be the responsibility of the registrar to determine if the paying parent is reliable enough to do this. This measure will reduce administration costs by providing greater flexibility to both the payer and the registrar. It also removes a great impost on the employer. Another benefit is the privacy aspect. No longer will an employer need to know how much a person is paying in support.

The registrar may reject an application to pay direct if it is considered the payer will not meet their obligations. The payer, as well, may also appeal against this decision. If a payer does default on a payment, the registrar may require that future payments be withheld from the payer's employer. Payers who default will have strictly limited future access to this provision.

BREAK.PARA: Another consideration is the child support liabilities in property and spousal maintenance proceedings. This section will amend the Family Law Act to enable the court to take into account any future child support liabilities when maintenance and property settlements are being reached. This means that, when a couple divorce, the amount in future child support will be used to make a balanced decision on property settlements, even when no formal arrangements have been made. Presently, private child support arrangements between a divorced couple cannot be taken into account. Therefore, any decision made by the court may not adequately reflect the true circumstances of both parties. It will require couples to apply for an assessment so that the court can properly assess the situation.

There is a fourth part to the bill, which again reduces the burden on employers. It reduces from five to seven years the length of time they are required to retain child support records. This brings child support requirements into line with the Income Tax Assessment Act.

In the electorate, most males complain that, while they are willing to pay support, they feel they are paying too much. Currently, the inflexibility of payments, how much they are paying and to whom is a vexatious issue. There is also a feeling that the males, who are in the main non‐custodial parents, are discriminated against by the CSA. This has been reflected in telephone conversations and the attitude of some public servants towards these males. Women complain that payments are either not made on time or not made at all—a common problem throughout Australia. The problem of reassessment is also of significant concern. While this bill will not overcome many of the problems facing our constituents, it is a start.

The system we inherited is not working. My congratulations go to the member for Chifley (Mr Price) on the Price report. He did an excellent job. It is now up to the government to put these recommendations into place and I believe we are working toward that end—toward a satisfactory, fair and just assessment of this situation. It is hurting both custodial and non‐custodial parents. This issue has a wider impact on the community and it cannot be patched up with quick‐fix solutions. There is a need for a total overhaul because there is a disincentive to earn more money by non‐custodial parents.
Above all, the major consideration in this legislation needs to be the welfare of the children. That is what this government will be working toward in a fairer assessment of this legislation.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kelly, De-Anne, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise today to speak on the Child Support Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 1) 1996. The child support scheme was established in response to concerns about the adequacy of court ordered child maintenance. The child support scheme was introduced in two stages by the previous government. In June 1988, the Child Support Agency was set up to collect maintenance set under existing court orders.

SPEECH.PARA: Stage 2 of the scheme covered estrangements and separations from 1 October 1989 onwards. They were separated and dealt with in a different manner. The Child Support Agency could now collect maintenance based on a formula assessed and applied against the non‐custodial parent's relevant taxable income. Under this stage of the scheme as well, parents could apply for a review, while before 1 October 1989 parents had to go back to the court.

There are a number of very sound measures in the bill before us. The annualisation to the non‐custodial parent of overpayment to the custodial parent is a very sound recommendation. The reduction from seven years to five years for records to be kept by employers is another very sound measure.

I want to refer now to November 1994, and the Joint Select Committee on Certain Family Law Issues which brought down a report titled Child support scheme, an examination of the operation and effectiveness of the scheme. There were 161 recommendations in that report and we have heard previous speakers speak of the number of submissions that were made to that particular committee.

There were many reasons why the last election was lost, but I would have to say that there is no doubt that the deficiencies in the Child Support Agency have been a significant factor in distress out there amongst non‐custodial and custodial parents.

The most universal complaint that comes into my office relates to either the Family Court or Child Support Agency or both. The usual complaint is that the process is inflexible, slow and difficult to understand. Parents complain that they are inundated by incomprehensible paperwork from the Child Support Agency, that the length of time required for a review prolongs financial hardship and the system is too rigid to take into account individual circumstances.

The most common concern of non‐custodial parents is that the rate of child support is unfair and does not give sufficient consideration to the income of the custodial parent. There has never been a suggestion that non‐custodial parents should not have to pay child support. All of them recognise their responsibilities and are willing to care for and support their children. All they ask is that the system needs to be more equitable and take into account second families, variations in weekly income and assessment on net rather than gross income.

The most common concern of custodial parents is the failure of the Child Support Agency to enforce maintenance payments and to collect arrears. It is my understanding that about 40 per cent of non‐custodial parents make little or no contribution to the maintenance of their children.

I would like to go through some of the difficulties that come into my office regarding child support. First of all I would like to mention comments made yesterday by the member for Werriwa (Mr Latham). He has been extremely flattering, in fact, to the government. He has been demanding that in the 12 months since we have come into government we make good all of the problems that have been raised by the previous government. I must say that I am vastly flattered to think that in 12 months we would be able to overcome the vast range of problems that have been left by 13 years of previous government. Certainly the bill before us with the measures that I have mentioned will go a great way towards ameliorating some of the difficulties raised by the inadequacies in the previous legislation.

I would like to now draw on some of those measures that do need to be addressed in the future. There needs to be some tie between access and child support payments. There is no doubt that there is a great deal of distress amongst parents—non‐custodial parents—who pay out substantial sums relative to their income and yet have no possibility of seeing their children. I would like to give you a couple of instances. A non‐custodial parent in my area was hospitalised for a very serious accident and during that time of course signed a great deal of paperwork on behalf of the hospital and himself. Unbeknownst to him, one of these was paperwork to allow his children to be taken to another country. He is only able once a year to pay the air fare for one child to come back to Australia when, of course, that access is permitted. He still pays high child support payments and is, understandably, very distressed at the situation.

Another non‐custodial parent, this time, of course, a father as well, had a de facto who left after a few months. He has not seen the child in the past five years. The custodial parent moves a great deal—frequently in fact—and when he is able to find out their location, he is able to make a phone call. He pays quite a substantial amount of his income and finds it very distressing that he cannot enjoy seeing his child grow up or be able to maintain a bond that would see a rich relationship when the child reached adulthood. I believe that there needs to be some tie between access and child support payments.

One of the other concerns that certainly needs addressing is the assessment of maintenance on a sliding scale according to a child's age, rather than as a fixed percentage of income. While it is reasonable to suggest that a child's living costs will vary according to the level of income of his or her parents, the calculation of child support as a percentage of income is unfair, as it does not take into account the real cost of raising a child. Regrettably, in our area, where we have a lot of isolated mining communities, a lot of men on quite high incomes—but relative to the difficulties of the task at hand and to the isolation—have found that it is not uncommon for them to almost be farmed out.

There are instances of custodial parents who have children by three different fathers receiving very comfortable child support payments and receiving, naturally, a third of the property. It is very regrettable to those non‐custodial parents that they have spent very little time with their children. They have had very little opportunity to form a bond with their children. They are paying very high maintenance payments. Their children quite often live in other parts of Australia once the custodial parent has left, and they are very regretful of the high amounts of maintenance that they pay.

Let me give an example of what happens when a payment is made on the gross income rather than the net, based on the examples of two non‐custodial parents in my area. After paying child support for two children, a parent who earns $40,000 per year gross is left with a net income of around $17,500. A non‐custodial parent who is earning $25,000 per year, who pays child support for two children, is left with a net income of $15,500—very much the same as the other non‐custodial parent earning substantially more. There is very little incentive in the existing scheme for overtime to be undertaken, for work to be undertaken in isolated areas, for people to travel to work, because the calculation on gross income leaves very little living wage for the non‐custodial parent.

Another situation is raising the non‐custodial parent's self‐support component. Currently, $8,733 is allowed for the self‐support component of a non‐custodial parent's income. But this is very low and acts as a disincentive for non‐custodial parents to continue working, particularly those who are on low incomes. A non‐custodial parent in my area earns $25,000 a year and pays child support for two children. This parent is left with a personal annual income of $15,500 after tax—that is about $300 a week. Unemployment benefits start at $320 per fortnight, along with rent assistance and the benefits of a health care card. This parent is seriously considering unemployment as an option, because the amount that he is left with to cover living expenses is so very low.

There needs to be some consideration of second families in child support assessment. There is no doubt, as I have said previously, that all parents wish to care for and maintain their children, but there has to be a recognition at some time that a relationship has ceased—not the relationship with the children, but the relationship with the other parent. People need to have an incentive to go on, to work, to make bonds, to start life afresh.

It is very unfair if one parent has the wherewithal and the financial means to do so, and the other has not. This creates a feeling of great bitterness amongst many non‐custodial parents, who are not in a position to start a new life or a new family. I will give an example.

BREAK.PARA: I have had the second wife of a non‐custodial parent in my office in tears because, if the existing system continues, once the child support payments have been made—quite properly, and there is no argument about that—to the non‐custodial parent's children of the previous marriage, once car payments have been made and tax has been paid, the couple does not have enough money left to make the payments on the house they are trying to buy together—and they have a small child. There is no doubt that they will lose their home. I do not believe that it is reasonable that anyone should lose their home through making child support payments.

To give you an example, one parent in my electorate has an annual income of $40,000, pays $325 per fortnight in child support for two children, and is left with a net weekly income of about $350. The parent has remarried, has a small, young, second family, and wants to have yet another child. They are finding it very difficult to make house payments and to care for the second family to a level that meets the amount of child support that is being paid to the original family.

Another matter that causes great distress is accountability for the use of maintenance payments by the custodial parents. Let me give you an example of one very distressed non‐custodial parent who has come into my office. They pay $300 in child support per fortnight for two children but, virtually every week since the relationship broke down, they have had the principal of the school calling and asking them to bring lunches to the school because the children do not have food, or calling because the children do not have sports uniforms or are not wearing shoes. It is not acceptable, certainly to this parent, that they pay what they believe is quite a substantial sum and yet their children are going without school lunches, shoes and adequate clothing. They are fairly basic things to ask a custodial parent to provide.

I believe that there should be some form of trust set up for any extra money, over and above the basic maintenance of the child, to be set aside to be available for the children's future. As many non‐custodial parents have pointed out to me, while they are paying high amounts, it plainly does not cost $150 a week to care, for instance, for a three‐year‐old, certainly not for a healthy child. They would like to see the excess put aside for the child's secondary or tertiary education, or perhaps to start them off in life when they start a trade or a business.

There is another difficulty, though, and that is of course for those 40 per cent of custodial parents who receive little or no child support payments. There must be a more effective enforcement of maintenance payments, and pursuit of arrears accrued by non‐custodial parents.

One situation that has arisen in my area is that, as I have mentioned, the unemployment benefits are quite attractive to those who would like to escape child support payments. But another situation has arisen, and it is not uncommon for custodial parents to come into my office and say that the non‐custodial parent has chosen to become a student and to get their Austudy partly as a loan, which means that they make no maintenance payment whatsoever. That seems to me a fairly poor situation, and at least a very modest amount should be paid by a non‐custodial parent towards their children's upkeep. Even a modest amount would be a recognition that they realise that they have a responsibility not only to make maintenance payments but also to care for their children.

I would simply like to conclude by saying that many excellent recommendations have been made in the report of the Joint Select Committee on Certain Family Law Matters, and I believe that they do need to be addressed. Table 1 on page 48 would be an excellent place to start, with the basic child support formula. The maximum income base or the cap certainly needs to be addressed. The basic self‐support component needs to be increased. Presently, it is at quite a low rate, and I believe that the self‐support component should be increased so that the non‐custodial parent is left with at least a reasonable sum to live on. The disregarded income level certainly needs to be reduced. Child support must be reduced, once the income is greater than that allowable to receive the pension—this, of course, is for the custodial parent. There are some excellent recommendations in that report, and we would do well to address them.

In conclusion, it is very important—and one of the other members has made the point—that we should not raise expectations. No government, no matter how responsible, can foresee the myriad of different financial and personal circumstances involved in the sadness of a family breakdown, and with second families as well. No government is going to be able to address all of those circumstances.

What we can do is aim for fairness. Non‐custodial parents, in the majority, are pleased and willing to contribute financially to their child's welfare. But there must be a recognition that both parents must be left with sufficient money, and that includes those custodial parents who are not getting any child support payments as well. There needs to be fairness to encourage both parents to continue working. There needs to be fairness to encourage parents to be responsible, and to take a positive and meaningful approach to their marriage breakdown and to maintaining a bond with their children. There needs to be fairness to enable both parents to start a new life, with mutual recognition that they owe an obligation to the children of their first relationship. I welcome the measures in this bill and look forward to further measures which bring fairness to the child support debate.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Price, Roger, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —We are talking about the Child Support Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 1) 1996 and I want particularly to associate myself with the second reading amendment moved by the honourable member for Werriwa (Mr Latham). I will not read that amendment again into Hansard , but we do express concern about the failure to respond to the recommendations of the report of the Joint Select Committee into Certain Family Law Issues. We believe that the government should be concerned about the wellbeing and welfare of all families, whether they are intact families, separated families, single parent families or serial families.

SPEECH.PARA: I want to do a few things this morning in relation to this issue. I would just like to recap that, as much as one can be critical of the Child Support Agency and the scheme, the pre‐existing scheme was terrible; it was a joke. I think all members should be supportive of the child support scheme. Indeed, as the President of the Senate says on frequent occasions, and quite rightly—she was deputy chairman of the committee—the child support scheme was introduced with bipartisan support.

I do not want to go over all the recommendations but I do want to address the philosophy of where the committee was coming from—that is, that no government can continue to fund an expanding agency like the Child Support Agency. Even under the present government, the numbers have still continued to increase. We have to say that there needs to be an agency where child support is collected and enforced, but that that agency should not be a `first in' agency. In other words, we have got to contract the role of the agency, I believe, to being a safety net agency. That is, where arrangements cannot be concluded amicably amongst the parties, then there is the Child Support Agency. Where payers have a good record of collection, we need to get them out of the agency. That is what this report is all about. And there was a whole raft of other recommendations.

BREAK.PARA: A recent criticism of the report—I want to plead guilty to it—is that the report deals inadequately with repartnered couples. I can say that that is actually there, but I plead guilty to that issue. What I have to say is that this report was brought down three years ago. No-one who was a member of the committee ever suggested that these recommendations should be set in concrete. What we did say is that these recommendations form the basis of reform, but a scheme like the Child Support Agency needed to be constantly monitored.

I know that the government, following a recommendation, is commissioning a study into the cost of children. Can I say that one of the good things about this is that it looks at how the formula is derived, the historical development of it in America and the development of different models trying to determine the cost of children. If people are holding their breath, expecting that this New South Wales study is going to give us all the solutions in terms of changing the formula or changing the percentages, they are wrong, they will not get that.

I have always said that we need to put a thermometer out there in voter‐land and sample reality. The only way we can do that is by actually looking at household income. We need to do that about a different set of circumstances for custodial and non‐custodial. Then it will be understood how well, how fairly and how equitably the formula is operating. Now no such study is being undertaken. There is no such study that we were able to draw on and I sincerely regret that.

We did make recommendations to change the formula and can I say how much they were going to cost? One of the things I always try to do, when a report is brought down, is to get some sense of what the cost to the government is. It is no good bringing down these marvellous recommendations that will never be implemented because of impracticality. It was going to cost the government $13 million to introduce the formula changes. There is criticism on both sides. Non-custodial parents say to me that that formula change is not going to go far enough, that it will not do enough, and probably they are right. Custodial parents have also expressed some concern. But this was the basis for making a change.

I have to say that Senator the Hon. Jim Short, when he was Assistant Treasurer, starting distributing ministerial correspondence, to which I took some offence. He used to write to people and say—and I presume that government backbenchers passed it on—that the committee had not recommended to change the percentages in the formula. Absolutely true, but it is a half‐truth. We did make recommendations to the formula and he never conceded that point and I think that is grossly unfair.

I have never responded to the minority report in this committee report and I feel that I need to do so now—it had been perhaps a mistake on my part. Firstly, Senator Neal says that she would like to see stage 1 cases brought under the scheme. Can I say that this was extensively considered by the committee and the consensus of opinion was that arrangements had been made under stage 1 and that to then change the conditions because of the new scheme would have involved an unfair element of retrospectivity.

We have, as parliamentarians, treated stage 1 custodial parents poorly and I really think that, under the legal aid system, we need to try to identify these people and ensure that, if there is a need for a variation in the Family Court for the amount, we write to them and make sure that they understand that relief is available and fund those cases. That would be far fairer than bringing them into stage 2, but I have to say that the children are growing up and each year there are fewer of them.

I have some sympathy with the recommendation but I do not have any sympathy for the next two recommendations. Firstly, it was to resist reducing the cap on non‐custodial incomes—that is, the amount at which the formula no longer applies. Now there are two reasons why it was set at 2.5 per cent. The first reason was that when the scheme was originated there was no ability for custodial parents to get a departure other than going to the Family Court.

No matter how imperfect the child support review officer scheme is—and we certainly recognise that it is imperfect—there is now an ability to get a departure that way. So by setting it at 2.5 instead of two of average weekly earnings, the first reason is out, by fact. The second is that the consultative committee believed that you reach a point in income where the spending on children plateaus and then falls away.

Let me take a ridiculous example. Are we arguing that, if a non‐custodial parent earns $1 million, then the custodial parent should be receiving $180,000 in child support? I do not think so. We are not talking about an income of $1 million here but I am making the point. If this is contested, let there be research. But that is what is stated. Those issues are not addressed by Senator Neal in her comments.

The other recommendation relates to dropping the disregarded income level. What we are talking about here is that, if you drop the disregarded income level of the custodial parent to the pension cut‐off point, 91 per cent of custodial parents are completely unaffected—there is no change to their child support. So we are talking about approximately nine per cent of custodial parents. What is the effect of it? I give you again the one‐child case. We have said that the withdrawal rate should only be 50c—in other words, if $1 of income is earned by a custodial parent over and above that figure, 50c is taken off the income of the non‐custodial parent. So you are talking about a withdrawal rate of 9c in the dollar. This is for the so‐called best‐off custodial parents. How ridiculous to suggest, as is suggested in the minority report, that it is a disincentive to work and that it is going to seriously affect custodial parents—it is plainly ridiculous.

One of the approaches that I really appreciate about the honourable member for Werriwa is that he said he is not going to tackle these issues of child support on a gender equity basis, he is going to tackle them on an equity and fairness basis. I think that that is long overdue. When people like me and other members of this parliament serve on a committee such as this, which concerns a difficult area, I guess I get a bit uptight when other people cannot resist trying to label us as being pro‐this or anti‐that.

I am in favour of families: intact families, separated families, single‐parent families, serial families; I think they are all made up of humans. I do not believe, for example, that there is a primacy of women in a first relationship over and above women in a second and subsequent relationship. I believe that they are women. I do not believe that they lose 10 per cent of their gender because they are actually marrying someone for the second time. I totally reject the minority report here. I always thought people would go and have a look at what the Main Committee said about those recommendations. That is why I have never highlighted it, but I am highlighting it now.

The other thing I wanted to say to the Main Committee is that there has been a sense of frustration, I think, by all who have served on that committee that the recommendations have not been implemented. But I want to say that I have prepared a private members bill that introduces the formula recommendations proposed in the report. I have not deviated one millimetre from what was recommended—not one step further, not one step back, with my private members bill. Of course, Mr Deputy Speaker, private members bills require the government to pick them up to have them implemented. I cannot give you the updated cost of that and only remind you that three years ago the cost to revenue was $13 million. Let me say that these are minimalist proposals, really minimalist.

In the absence of decent information this is what we could come up with. I have said before that I believe that the committee was the best informed group of people before the inception of the child support scheme, after the inception and ever since, in terms of the information that we had available to us—more than the consultative group, more than the ministerial committee. But even so it was inadequate. You can see the modelling of the effects of the committee in the appendices of the report. We would have liked to have gone further, but we could not.

I also need to say that when we requested about eight different variations to be modelled by the Department of Social Security, it took the department six months and it took a technical upgrade of the computer. One wonders, given the monopoly of the Department of Social Security on modelling information, how vigorously and rigorously it was monitoring it. But I reiterate that you are not going to get any idea of the impact of the scheme until you look at disposable income.

One of the matters mentioned by the member for Dawson (Mrs De‐Anne Kelly) was that of access and child support. This was considered by the committee, and I can say that both Daryl Williams and I felt very badly that we did not deal with the access issue in this report or in the subsequent report, and I have apologised for not having done so.

I do not know whether linking access and child support is going to get us anywhere, but I would commend to the honourable member for Dawson the speech that the Attorney‐General gave on 25 October, when he talked about taking all the non‐judicial functions from the Family Court and putting them in the Attorney‐General's Department, because a system is needed that allows non‐custodial parents to bring before a tribunal rather than a court the issue that access orders have not been fully carried out.

There is always a presumption in our system, and I think it should remain so, that the child should stay with the mother. It is going to take several attempts before a tribunal to demonstrate the lack of goodwill and good faith in carrying out those contact orders. But once you have done that, the whole issue of residency and who should have the child can then be raised again. I think that is the only way there will be some relief in this area.

I have to say that I support the Attorney‐General in taking the non‐judicial elements out of the Family Court. I hope that he will look at setting up a tribunal, because, in my electorate and I suspect also in the honourable member for Dawson's electorate, what people want—I am all for mediation—is arbitration. They want to be able to go to a tribunal—say, similar to the Small Claims Tribunal or the rent and residency tribunals in my state—and get a decision. They do not want to have these legal champions at the front while they are right at the back. They want to be able to argue there and have a decision, and not get themselves into debt and paying off the bank card.

Let me conclude on the following few points: there is a lot to be gained by custodial parents in some of the recommendations that have been unenacted to date, but I sincerely hope that there will be a time line put on by government members as to when they expect their government to bring down their version of these reforms. But do not think that we can fix child support and we have cleared the air. Child support is something that will require constant monitoring, but in particular there is the burden of family law as it stands today—inaccessible and not of assistance. The real test of the success of any government in family law will be actually allowing people to access it without bankrupting themselves or indebting themselves, and shifting the $100 million we spend on the Family Court and the $125 million in federal legal aid up the relationship chain.

PARA.EMPHASIS: A division having been called in the House of Representatives—
Sitting suspended from 11.41 a.m. to 11.53 a.m.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Johnston, Ricky, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —Before I start, I would like to commend the work that has been done by the member for Chifley (Mr Price). Not only is he very passionate about what he is doing, but he has also put a lot of work into it in previous years, and I congratulate him for it.

SPEECH.PARA: I have been waiting to speak to this bill for some time, as the child support scheme and the Child Support Agency are matters which feature much in my daily work. I mentioned in the grievance debate earlier this week that many members on both sides of the House are concerned with the large number of phone calls received each week dealing with issues relating to child support. Indeed, this issue is by far the most pressing and prevalent matter raised by people in our community. Seeking to implement appropriate amendments to the legislation is, thus, timely. Before addressing the specifics of the bill, I would like to refer to a statement made in the coalition's policy document, Certainty for families, which was released prior to the election last year. It said:

Australia's families, their values and their strengths, will determine the future of our country and the quality of the lives of Australians. The ideal of a secure and happy family is pre‐eminent among our national goals.
There is no doubt in my mind that members on both sides of the House will agree with this sentiment.

On a personal note, I am lucky enough to have a very happy family which has given me much joy and pleasure throughout many years, and I hope that they will continue to do so. However, as members of parliament, we come across thousands of people as part of our duties and we know that many families are not so lucky. In recent years Australia, along with many other countries, has experienced rising levels of unemployment and greater uncertainty. Such changes that are taking place globally have contributed to and, in some instances, led directly to the breakdown of many Australian families.

The resulting separation is often traumatic, particularly for children, and it ends up in heartbreak and confusion for all involved. We have seen the number of family break‐ups escalate as never before in this country. Separation and divorce are commonplace and the issue of who supports the children of these broken marriages is a huge question which most parents find difficult to address.

The objective of the child support scheme, which was established in the late 1980s, is to ensure that both custodial and non‐custodial parents pay for their children's upkeep. According to evidence given to the 1994 Joint Select Committee on Certain Family Law Issues, about one‐third of separated parents are clients of the Child Support Agency, with the rest collecting child support through an informal arrangement. Since 1991 the Commonwealth Ombudsman has received more complaints about the Child Support Agency per client than any other federal department or agency. The need for positive action to improve child support so as to make it more fair and equitable for all involved is most urgent.

So here we are today addressing the Child Support Legislation Amendment Bill introduced into the parliament last year. This bill contains three measures which were announced by the previous government in the 1995‐96 federal budget. These changes are proposed as a response to a small number of recommendations made by the Joint Select Committee on Certain Family Law Issues. As the former Assistant Treasurer said in his second reading speech:
The package of measures included in the bill are aimed at increasing flexibility, reducing the level of intrusiveness and improving certainty and clarity in the law.

One of the measures in this bill that I particularly approve of, and it is dealt with in items 31 to 39, cuts the employer out of the process of child maintenance payments. These changes will allow a parent to elect to pay his or her child support directly to the Child Support Agency, as recommended by the joint select committee. I would like to quote from the committee's report on this matter as I believe this excerpt to be very important. It says:

The joint committee considers it important that the intrusiveness of the scheme be minimised and that parents should be given a choice in deciding the means by which they pay their child support liabilities. While child support continues to be paid on a regular basis, non-custodial parents should be able to pay the CSA through the mechanism of their choice. If a non-custodial parent defaults on child support payments, the child support registrar could immediately contact the non‐custodial parent's employer to commence autowithholding of child support. This would avoid the necessity of unnecessary disclosure of personal information to the non‐custodial parent's employers and offer an incentive to non‐custodial parents to comply voluntarily with their child support obligations.

I know that there are many people in my electorate of Canning, and throughout Australia, who will welcome this change. Many constituents have come to seek my assistance over the past year, horrified that their employer knew all about their personal and private situation without letting them know first.

One gentleman with whom I have had many dealings about the Child Support Agency only found out that his employer was fully aware of his personal situation two and half years after he started to work with that company. What is worse, that employer had been given a false impression by the Child Support Agency about this gentleman's character and this, consequently, reflected badly on the gentleman in his workplace. And to top this all off, he only found out about this by sheer chance. He was very upset that his employer had all this information about him. People deserve a basic right to privacy, especially when they have been doing the right thing. It is my opinion that employers should be privy to this information on a need-to-know basis only.

This measure will also reduce the compliance costs for employers as the number of payers electing to pay directly to the registrar increases, as one could well assume. Another aspect of the main provisions in this bill is the use of election where income has changed. As members would be aware, child support assessments are based on each parent's relevant income for the child support year. These assessments are then calculated by looking at income tax returns from the previous two years. A possibility exists for parents to have their positions reassessed if they believe their income for the current year will be more than 50 per cent less than they anticipated.

It is often the case that an income estimate election results in the paying parent being entitled to receive a refund from the person receiving support, due to an overpayment. But, from talking to my constituents, I get a very clear picture that this causes a terrible inconvenience for the parent who has already received the payments in good faith and spent the money for the benefit of the children he or she looks after. Items 21 to 25 of schedule 1 of the bill propose to amend the Child Support (Assessment) Act 1989 to modify the effect of making an income estimate election on child support liability.

As the explanatory memorandum to the bill notes, the proposed amendments will generally leave undisturbed the amounts payable prior to making the income estimate election and only affect future amounts payable. The proposed amendments will: firstly, reduce the incidence of overpayments to persons receiving child support which currently arise because of the retrospective effect of an income estimate election; secondly, better reflect a payer's future capacity to pay, because the amount payable will only be changed for the month remaining after the estimate has been lodged; and, thirdly, reduce the level of child support arrears that may arise when payers spend amounts refunded to them as overpayments, but later do not have the funds to meet their revised ongoing child support liability.

There is no doubt that those changes to the legislation will remove a very significant cause for complaint amongst many people who have dealings with child support and the agency. The third major provision in the bill relates to the Family Law Act 1975. Under the existing law, where a person is paying child support voluntarily and without an assessment of his or her child support liability, the amounts paid under these arrangements cannot be taken into account. The present situation may result in courts making orders which do not adequately reflect the true circumstances of the parent who is to pay child support.

It is important to note that this means that parents must apply for an assessment even if they wish to make their own private arrangements regarding child support. The court can then take these commitments into account when making orders regarding property or maintenance to their former spouse. This measure will ensure that those separated parents with private arrangements for child support will be treated the same way as parents who are currently paying child support through the agency.

To sum up, I am pleased to be able to speak to this bill today. It is the first stage of what I hope will be many changes to the child support system and the Child Support Agency. Whilst the changes are just the beginning, they are a most welcome start. They are a move in the right direction to ensure a fairer system for all. They are the first step along a long path to ensure that changes are made to the child support arrangements in this country. Indeed, the parents and children of Australia deserve a better and fairer system.

Yesterday, the member for Werriwa (Mr Latham) said in the Main Committee that this government should have done more, seeing that we have been in government for 12 months. It needs to be noted that the Labor Party had ample time to right the wrongs perceived within the child support system during their years in government. One can only hope that, for the benefit of all Australians who are caught up in the web of this disastrous system, we can look forward to a bipartisan approach to solve this problem. I commend the bill to the Main Committee.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to speak, perhaps somewhat briefly, in support of the Child Support Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 1) 1996 and the amendments moved by the member for Werriwa (Mr Latham). The amendments, as put so succinctly by the member for Chifley (Mr Price) in his submission to the Main Committee, do not entail to any great degree, or with any great degree of emphasis, notions of gender, but rather focus almost totally on initiatives based on equity.

BREAK.PARA: The establishment of the Child Support Agency by the Labor government in 1988 was at that time, and still is today, a major breakthrough in the difficult and often intransigent problem of child maintenance after the end of a marriage. There is an increasingly high rate of divorce. For example, in my electorate of Isaacs, in the south‐eastern growth corridor, first home owners move out in search of the great Australian dream, buy a home and then the marriage dissolves. The divorce rate is particularly high in that area, so our office is well versed in problems associated with divorce and the subsequent problems involving child support and maintenance.

This is not only a problem which vexes Isaacs but it also vexes all of Australia and, indeed, much of the Western world. One only has to hark back to the 1996 American presidential campaign when President Bill Clinton referred, on a regular basis, to a crackdown on what he called `deadbeat dads' as part of his election policy.
When introducing the child support scheme in 1988, the then Labor government and its Minister for Social Security, Mr Brian Howe, spoke of the rationale behind it. He said at that time:

Many Australian families have experienced the pain of marriage breakdown. That is something that governments can do little to help—but government can take action to alleviate dramatic and sustained drops in living standards for children in those families. Poverty has for too long been the traumatic result of marriage breakdown for children in sole parent families.
The minister went on to say:
This scheme will ensure that parents who have the capacity to pay do not abandon the financial responsibility of supporting their children to the social security system.

Those, like myself, who recall his comments at that time, will remember that he also quoted some alarming statistics, including that over half the Australian children living in poverty are in sole parent families. Also of note was the fact that some 70 per cent of non‐custodial parents were not paying regular maintenance or child support for their children.

I know that both sides of the House would recognise that the child support program has had considerable success in addressing this problem. I acknowledge, as has the member for Canning (Mrs Johnston), the passionate contribution of the member for Chifley and his work in this area over an ongoing period of time. The coalition, however, in its pre‐election policy release, said that it:

. . . supports the concept of child support, recognising that it is the responsibility of both parents to share in the financial support of their children after separation according to their capacity to do so.

The bill we are dealing with today reflects changes to the operation of the program, which were announced by the Keating government in its 1995‐96 budget. A major effect of the package is that it streamlines a number of administrative elements in the child support scheme.

I should point out at this stage that I consider that the Child Support Agency does indeed do a wonderful job under very trying conditions and circumstances. I know, from many of the cases that our office deals with—cases which, I am sure, are not too dissimilar from those dealt with by the 147 other offices around the country—that any dealings with people who have been through painful marriage break‐ups need a great deal of sensitivity and patience; and it has been my experience that the Child Support Agency has exhibited, in large part, capacities in both those areas.

Similarly, our office receives many complaints from constituents, more often than not from custodial parents who feel that their ex‐spouses may not be paying sufficient maintenance or that the Child Support Agency is perhaps somewhat overly bureaucratic and plays too great an administrative role in its approach to their particular problem. Often our office forms a view that these complaints are unreasonable but, even where they are deemed to be reasonable, they do demonstrate a clear need for the workings of the child support scheme to be simplified, updated and, indeed, further improved.

Landmark programs such as the Child Support Agency will always need close scrutiny and review. When the legislation was introduced back in 1988, there was some expectation that this would be a necessary and, indeed, integral part of the development of the scheme. As a number of teething problems began to emerge through the earlier years of the operation of the Child Support Agency—and perhaps for most of us there were too many teething problems—the Joint Select Committee on Certain Family Law Issues took submissions and tabled a report on the operation and effectiveness of the child support scheme. That report was tabled in November 1994. As I believe the Member for Chifley has noted, the report recommended that some 163 changes be made to the scheme.

The package of measures contained in legislation currently before the parliament perhaps addresses some of the areas that were identified as needing both amendment and improvement. As I understand it, the package reflects changes proposed by the former Labor government in its last, 1995‐1996, budget. These were in fact the first of quite a number of refinements that the previous government had planned to implement in response to the findings of this committee—something which, again, the Member for Chifley has spoken at length about.

Members would by now be well aware that the underlying thrust of this bill is to implement changes whereby custodial parents will not have to refund overpayments but will instead have future payments for the forthcoming year reduced commensurately. It also implements changes whereby non‐custodial parents will be able to make their payments direct to the Child Support Agency rather than to their employer. As I know the member for Dickson (Mr Tony Smith) understands, employers often obtain details of such matters well in advance of the employee affected by any particular issue of this nature. When making property or maintenance decisions, the Family Court will, under the changes proposed by this bill, be able to take into account future liabilities under the Child Support (Assessment) Act 1989, even if an assessment has not at that time been made.

Parents have the right to apply to the registrar to vary the amount of their liability, the result often being either that the custodial parent is forced, or perhaps coerced, to repay an amount of money which has already been spent on children, or conversely that a paying parent is forced to repay most, or indeed all, in some cases, of the amount refunded over the remainder of the year. Under the present system, variations to a paying parent's liability under the scheme has, therefore, proven to be an extremely inconvenient measure and a financially difficult arrangement for both the custodial and the non‐custodial parent.

The purpose of the amendment proposed by the member for Werriwa is to allow for what might best be described as a more accurate reflection of a payer's capacity to pay, because the amount payable will be charged only for the months remaining after the estimate has been lodged. It will also mean that it will be less likely for a custodial parent to be compelled to make such repayments.

An amendment to the Child Support (Registration and Collection) Act 1988 will give payers the opportunity to make payments directly to the Child Support Registrar. The only caveat to this is that the registrar be satisfied that the person will indeed make these payments.

The benefit of this change includes a saving in administrative costs which would otherwise have been incurred in an attempt to make employers comprehend and come to terms with the operation of the scheme and their responsibilities. Also it affords the opportunity for far greater choice for the non‐custodial parent in their method of payment. Of course, many payers opt to make payments directly to the registrar rather than through their employer, which has obvious advantages when it comes to delicate and sensitive issues of privacy and confidentiality. Essentially, this change reflects greater discretion in the way the collection of child support is administered.

At present, any voluntary child support arrangements are not taken into account by the Family Court in either property or spousal maintenance proceedings. This bill will have the effect of treating these arrangements in the same way as a child support assessment and will consequently allow the court to assess more accurately the financial circumstances of the parties to these proceedings. There are also what might best be described as consequential changes to related acts, but I shall not go into those on this occasion.

In drawing my comments to a close, I remind the Committee of the amendment put forward by the honourable member for Werriwa, which criticises the Howard government for its failure to act upon the recommendations flowing from the joint select committee's findings. This is something that the member for Chifley has elaborated on at some length, and it is not my intention to do so at this stage. Suffice it to say that the coalition did say in its pre‐election policy release:
The Coalition believes that the most grave and chronic problems with the child support scheme are not being adequately addressed by the government.
The Coalition will fully address the concerns of the Joint Select Committee into Certain Family Law Issues.

Now that we are more than 12 months down the track, it is the view of those on this side of the Main Committee that the government is showing little sign of addressing the concerns of the Joint Select Committee into Certain Family Law Issues.

We urge the government to address this most serious of issues, and stand ready to support any proposals submitted by parliamentarians to improve the scheme's working, fairness and administration. I commend the bill, and the amendments moved by the member for Werriwa, to the Main Committee and the House.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Smith, Tony, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —It has been said before today that the world's worst wreck is a broken marriage. When you peer into the reasons—as no‐one should do—you are really peering into a person's private bedroom. The public at large has no place in that particular area, as I am sure most people would agree. What the child support act and the amendments in the Child Support Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 1) 1996 try to do is to effect some sort of logical, ordered process to deal with those wrecks. Unfortunately, I do not believe the child support act is capable of doing that.

SPEECH.PARA: I welcome any improvement in that process, but I have a fundamental reservation about the ability of the act as it presently stands to be able to effect an orderly maintenance regime. That basically stems from the fact that the act purports to cover everybody, and everybody is different. Every single situation is different—and that was the beauty of the court process, because that process looked at every individual situation and was able to adjust the rate of maintenance on the basis of need and capacity to pay. Those were the two principles that were echoed, day in and day out, in the old maintenance courts of this land before this horrible system came into play.

I am not saying that the previous system worked well. It worked in part and it did effect a lot of satisfactory results. On the other hand, with the advances of the supporting parent pension and the social security structure, parties would inevitably reach private little deals in order for that pension to be kept up. That was wrong; that was a fraud on the Australian taxpayer. The Australian taxpayer is not liable to support other people's children. I think somebody has already made that point. The Australian taxpayer obviously has an acute acknowledgment of helping those who have fallen through the safety net. By the same token, it has to be stated and stated again.

I get extremely annoyed when I hear of those—and it seems to be mainly fathers—who just refuse to pay any maintenance for their children. Sometimes there are circumstances such as lack of access which impinge on all of that, and I can understand that. But I cannot cope with the notion that any person can say, `I am not paying for children that I have had the responsibility of bringing into the world.' It is anathema to me. I do not know of any person who has come to my office—and they have been numerous, both in person and through telephone contact—who has not acknowledged that they would be happy to pay a reasonable amount of maintenance. It gets back to that issue of need and capacity to pay. That concept was blown out of the door by the operation of the child support act. I should add that I do not believe anybody should avoid paying something for child support.

I believe someone on unemployment benefits should be able to maintain a payment of $10 a week to a child. But under the child support regime, they get out of paying maintenance for their children and I do not think that is right either. Every person has a responsibility. I have had a young mother come to me and say, `Look, if I had $5 a week I could send the kids off to a school excursion'—five dollars a week out of a recalcitrant non‐payer who is on an unemployment benefit.

There has to be a regime where every person must take responsibility. I include in that particularly the recalcitrant small business people who are able to get out of paying. Unfortunately, as I have said before in this House, the child support act does not enforce its own objects. In its objects it says that it is there to relieve the person from having to go to court, but in the next breath it makes an assessment on a subjective basis that the person who is supposed to pay child support cannot pay. It hears some evidence from that person that that person has not got any income. It hears some other evidence by way of some casual phone calls or what have you from other people and then it makes an assessment that `That person cannot pay, therefore we will not chase that person.'

Every small business person that I know hates going to court. One way you can always get some money out of somebody who owes a debt—and child support is a debt as much as anything else—is to take them to court. Rather than being cross‐examined or having to bring all the records of their business to court, they miraculously find a settlement before they get to court. But the Child Support Agency is not doing its job in that regard—I have said that before and I will keep saying it—because it is not upholding its own objects in the act.

While I am on my feet about this matter, I think it is necessary to refer to some hypocrisy in the amendment to this legislation. The Price report came out in November 1994 with something approaching 150 recommendations. We have an amendment moved by the member for Werriwa (Mr Latham). Let me say in relation to that honourable member that he has made some quite good suggestions during the Christmas break. He made a number of forays into the media and I have to concede that some of the suggestions he made in relation to the family tax package and the child support deductibility components were very good. By the same token, when one looks at this amendment it is a monumental piece of snake oil salesmanship. When there was a report of that nature which had 150 or so recommendations and which was sitting gathering dust, and the previous government did not address the core issues raised by that report—it addressed some peripheral issues which this legislation also addresses—for him to come in here and say that the government has failed in its undertakings is really a monumental piece of mirror shuffling and card shuffling. At the end of the day the amendment can be seen for what it is: basically a piece of political chicanery.

But leaving that aside, I think it is important to give credit where credit is due, and acknowledge that some honourable members, including the honourable member for Werriwa, have made constructive suggestions in relation to the matter. It is a matter that covers the whole of Australia. In my electorate I have something of the order of 42 per cent, I think, of first marriages failing and a higher percentage of subsequent marriages failing. Almost every honourable member who has spoken on this matter has said that it is the biggest source of aggravation in one's electorate office. These measures do go part of the way but they do not get, and they are not pretending to get, to the heart of the matter. We have to address the formula, the needs and the capacity to pay principle, and we have to address some way of objectively departing from that formula in individual cases.

Everybody has got to have their day in court or in a tribunal. What I am suggesting is that we set up a small claims tribunal to handle these particular matters—let us call it a family support tribunal. It does not matter what name we give it, but it has to be a situation where there is not the absurdity of the child support review, where people proffer false documents and try to induce the review officer to give departures from assessments.
