Evidence is not given on oath, and I am not aware of any penalty for proffering false evidence—there may be a minor penalty but it is not a perjury matter. When you take an oath and you swear that something is true and it is false, that is a serious charge. That is what we have to bring into the system in order for the system to work properly.

When I appeared in court on these sorts of matters I never saw a situation where the applicant did not come to court with extraordinary claims. I can recall back in the early 1980s people claiming $300 a week maintenance for one young child. All these claims were jacked up and added to—every imaginable claim was made—but when you stripped it all away, a figure usually under $100—and frequently around the $50 mark in those days—was considered a very reasonable amount when the evidence was heard.

But with the formula that is now in place there is an extraordinary situation where a child of one year of age is assessed by way of the child support system in the same fashion as a child of 14 years of age. What an absurdity that is and what aggravation that creates for the parent concerned—the parent who is paying—who believes that effectively it is a free lunch and a holiday for the custodial parent—and it is in some cases.

That is the sort of situation we have to address ultimately for this legislation to survive. I have to say it is typical socialist type legislation. It is legislation that covers everybody whereas in fact each individual person has to be looked at in their own special set of circumstances. No legislation can do that, the state cannot do that. The state cannot draw legislation that covers every particular circumstance; only a court or tribunal can do that. If people see that they are getting some justice and are heard, they might have a chance to look at the matter and to accept the assessment that was made.

The bill does introduce some welcome amendments to the income estimate election provisions, but I want to mention the issue of employers. Unless employers have had some experience of this system they look at these assessments and see that in some cases there is a debt which can be quite large. Sometimes they see a penalty attached to it and they see the time that the debt has been subsisting. That creates in the mind of an employer the idea that the person involved, the paying party, is some sort of criminal—he is not paying for his kids. Frequently he is, and frequently the system is behind with its assessment. It is constantly sending notices every month that ignore any plea that the person gives by way of telephone or letter or otherwise. They do not bother replying. They do not bother phoning back. This letter comes across the employer's desk and the employer obviously cannot help but make a judgment about his employee. That is not good because an unscrupulous employer can abuse the system and is in a position to use that information adversely against his employee. That is a disgraceful example of the state peering into people's lives and then disseminating the information far and wide into their workplace. Whispers can spread, `Well, this bloke is no good; he doesn't pay maintenance for his kids.' Frequently he does, but the system does not catch up with it, so these letters continue to be sent.

It is important that the amending legislation gives paying parents a choice. They can continue with the system as it currently is or they can deal directly with the registrar and use a discretion. If they then default, first of all they can appeal any discretion exercised by the child support registrar against that particular move. In other words, they have got a right of appeal to change any decision by the registrar. At least it is some movement in the right direction on that particular score.

We are dealing with legislation that basically is on three wheels and has always been on three wheels. I do not pretend to have the answer—the answer is not a simple one. It is not one that can be done simply by the stroke of a pen, by a group of people running out and saying that this should be done or that should be done. It is a matter that is very complex, as has been mentioned by all people. But for political motives the amendment of the member for Werriwa pretends to the Australian community that we have ben sitting on our hands and doing nothing.

There is a very active government backbench committee on this matter, I can assure you, and it is a very complex matter. It is a matter that requires a lot of work and a lot of assessments by Treasury to look at the potential impact. But the members of the committee which is looking at it are taking in the views of their constituents and those views are getting back to the government as a whole and will continue to do so. I know that the member for Capricornia (Mr Marek) is one person who has led the charge on that and continues to do so. Despite some comments that have been made by the member for Werriwa, although I am sure he can defend himself, it is quite clear that he has been at the forefront of this particular debate. If you look through the Hansard, you will see that most of us have said something about this legislation over the last 12 months.

In the time left to me I emphasise again that this particular system is in very grave need of reform—I think everybody accepts that. In reality, piecemeal reform, while useful, does not ultimately solve the problem. I mentioned the child support percentage that is applied to taxable income of the liable parent and that it fails to take into account the age of the child eligible for administrative assessment. There is no basis in reality for this. As I have said, a six‐month‐old baby simply does not cost as much to maintain as a 15‐year‐old. The child support liability of a liable parent with a taxable income of $50,000 and no other dependants is $149.26 per week for one child, regardless of that child's age.

So one proposal I make is to amend the legislation for administrative purposes to reflect the age of the eligible child or, alternatively, have an independent tribunal. I favour more particularly that means to make the assessments of child support, thus relegating the Child Support Agency to a collection agency only. It needs teeth to collect, as I said before. Instead of being focused on the terrible emotional upheaval caused by marriage break‐up and the attendant problems that surround it, if the role of the Child Support Agency were focused primarily on collection and not on assessment or on the minutiae of problems associated with assessment and penalties and so forth—which I regard with horror, by the way—maybe we would get more of the recalcitrant non‐payers picked up.

It is said that there are something like 300,000 cases handled by the agency, and something like 2,500 complaints to the ombudsman in a recent survey. While it shows an enormous degree of complaint, it does not reflect the true state of affairs. People do not bother to go to the ombudsman to complain but, by gee, they go to their members to complain. One can judge and assess very well how a system is going when one looks at the number of complaints on this area.

I emphasise again that there is a cheap, effective and inexpensive way of taking a lot of heat out of this matter by putting these matters into a tribunal. The assessment has to be lower. But to get departures from it should be by way of evidence and cross‐examination on oath, preferably without lawyers, or with lawyers by leave. That would be a cheap and inexpensive way of trying to take the heat out of it, of trying to bring some objectivity to the whole situation, but with subjectivity because we must focus on the individuals concerned.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Andren, Peter, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —I have listened with much interest to the member for Dickson (Mr Tony Smith) and the commonsense suggestions that he has made in this area. I am well aware of the contribution he has made in this particularly worrisome area of policy because, from the day he entered the parliament, his first adjournment speech—
—Maiden speech.

—His maiden speech, he tells me, concentrated on that scheme. As a new member of this House, of all the issues I have had to deal with over the past year, I would say child support is one of the greatest concerns. In fact, it is taking up about 20 per cent of my workload in my electorate office and it seems, from talking to other members from both sides of the House, that they have similar workloads in this area.

SPEECH.PARA: It has reached the stage where I have had to look at sending my staff to special training sessions so they can learn how to counsel people in these situations, so stressful are the circumstances that they are having to deal with. I am having people come in on a regular basis seeking the support of my staff as their sole source of consultation, if you like, in this area. Through the diminution of legal aid and particularly through perceived inadequacies in the Family Court and the deal received by the non‐custodial parent—the father, in most cases—there is absolute total frustration.

I have been almost terrified at the passion and the anger that has been demonstrated by some of these clients. There have been examples almost of violence in terms of hitting walls and kicking chairs in the confines of my electorate office. That is the sort of anger that can be translated into the sort of crime that we see through the passion and the feeling of total isolation from any sort of meaningful support from the system. That is the sort of anger that is building up out there, and the sort of thing that will be on our heads if we do not move quickly to modify and to reform this area of law and assistance. People feel the whole system is working against them.

Enforced child support always follows a marriage or relationship breakdown and, more often than not, a child custody dispute. Those who part amicably do not require the intervention of the Child Support Agency. It might be handy to dismiss those people caught up in this as bitter and twisted. That was perhaps a perception that many may have had until they have had to come face to face with the reality, as all members are now, particularly through the lack of access to face‐to‐face counselling. People, particularly in regional areas, are being asked to access 1800 telephone numbers. Toll free lines are not the answer to these sorts of problems. One letter to me recently said:
It seems that Governments are quickly pro‐active when it comes to the economy and taxation, but strictly slow to react to issues outside the commercial core of our society.

What this man is saying is that we as politicians are putting money and budget deficits ahead of people. It is a very damning comment. Perhaps it is unfair, but I know for a fact that that man's view is shared by many and we cannot afford to ignore it. We know the number of marriage breakdowns in society is high. So many of them involve children and many of those children are being brought up exposed to an environment of frustration, bitterness and hatred.

By far the most angry and disgruntled group of people are the men who have lost custody of their children and have also lost out or come out with a lesser share in a divorce settlement. They are now paying substantial amounts of income in child support. In many cases their former wives have now found new partners and so have an extra income coming in. The way the men see it, they have lost their wife, their house and their kids, and are now continuing to lose a large slice of their income.

They may try to work overtime to get ahead, and also to provide the flats and the bedding that are required if they are going to have custody of or stays with the kids, or if they are going to have a holiday. They want to provide for that outside the amount of income that is being taxed for their child support. But then a large slice of the extra income goes as well. They have to give up the same proportion of their overtime, and that is one area of huge concern to these people. It is even further complicated if they then find a new partner and begin a second phase of family life, if you like. They do not have the income to support this second family.

What is the answer? I guess there is no simple one. It is not as simple as saying that the children are paramount and that the non‐custodial parent just has to face the facts of his or her obligations. From what I have seen, the non‐custodial parent is very often the major victim of the child support system. It is unnecessarily complex and frustrating.

This was brought home to me recently by a local abattoir worker, forced to move back home and live with his elderly parents because he could not afford to buy food and keep up his child support payments. Let us call this fellow Bill. Bill loves his children, has a good relationship with his former wife and respects his obligations to pay child support.

The problem arose when he became ill and went on sick leave. His normally high income, boosted by overtime and bonuses, was cut back significantly but his child support payments remained the same. All he could do to adjust the payments was to keep sending off a review form every two months. But he had a devil of a time getting the right advice and assistance. He got the run‐around between child support offices in Penrith and Canberra—and, as I have said, there is no person he could deal with face to face in the Orange area.

You have to wonder, in these days when we are all paid by direct deposit into bank accounts and the whole system is computerised, why child support cannot be automatically adjusted as a percentage of weekly earnings. Why does a man working in an occupation subject to massive seasonal fluctuations such as this one have to go through the ridiculous process of trying to estimate annual income every two months? If he gets it wrong, if the local abattoir suddenly has a very busy month, then he faces a penalty.

An honest man who is only trying to do his best by his former wife and children gets a boot in the rear at the end of the financial year for working his guts out. In fact, that is exactly what happened to this man at the end of last financial year. After all the forms he had put in all year, he was given an end of year bill from the Child Support Agency for $1,600. The agency says that it must have lost one of his forms. To top it off, his eldest son is now 16 and is working full time, but Bill is told that he still has to pay child support while the son is living at home with his mother.
The Child Support Agency says—understandably, because that is the rule—that there is nothing it can do unless the legislation is changed. It is about time it was changed.

It was as a result of this case, and the sheer frustration of this man in trying to understand how the system worked, that I asked the child support office to begin a series of field visits to my electorate. The response to these visits, to centres such as Bathurst and Orange, has been overwhelming. I commend the child support office for this very positive move, but I wonder why it took until now for it to happen and how on earth these people were coping beforehand.

I will go back to my friend the abattoir worker. I rang him after his visit to the Child Support Agency, on their visit to the electorate, to see if they were able to sort him out. He said no. The abattoir has just lost a major contract, so his income has plummeted again and he is back on struggle street trying to make his child support payments—and, of course, he is filling out more forms. At the same time, he is trying to scrape enough money together to meet that huge back payment he had to make after the CSA apparently lost one of his forms.

This is one man's story, one of the many hundreds of thousands out there. No doubt other members of the House have similar ones, as we have heard. Is it any wonder so many non-custodial parents in this situation throw in the towel, give up their full‐time job and go on the dole?

A mate of Bill told me that he liked working too much and he was not prepared to go on the dole. He said that he was doing seasonal work—fruit picking and so on. `So you're getting paid cash in the hand?' I said. No, he travels around with his new girlfriend and all the money they earn goes in her name. It is illegal and unfair, but this ridiculous, frustrating system is driving honest, law‐abiding people to do illegal things such as this. My first reaction when encountering cases such as this was, `They're only bitter and twisted that they have lost custody of the kids. How can they object?' Perhaps it is because it is mostly men in these situations that problems such as this are allowed to fester and are ignored by government.

If the shoe were on the other foot and it was mostly women who were the non‐custodial parents, would these problems be allowed to continue? Somehow, I doubt it. Women today are more empowered to take action against an injustice like this, I believe. Perhaps it is because it is mostly men who are disadvantaged and discriminated against by the child support system that these frustrating injustices have been allowed to exist for too long.

The changes taking place as a result of this bill are welcome and broadly supported and will once again make life a little easier for child support recipients. The bill will streamline the system so it is less likely that child support recipients will face the prospect of having to repay sums at the end of the year.

But over the past year I have received no more than three complaints from child support recipients concerned at problems in this area. Compare that with the hundreds of complaints I have received from people paying child support. These people are more inclined to complain about paying than receiving, but it would be wrong to suggest that all those complaining do not have some legitimate gripes with the system.

There are several worthwhile reforms in the bill that will assist all parties concerned, including employers, but it is not really going to make a great difference to those who need the most help. The lack of action by this government and the former one on the issue of child support is a classic example of why politicians are held in such low esteem.

The last time the issue was seriously examined was back in 1994 when the Joint Select Committee on Certain Family Law Issues handed down its report. Three members of this House were part of that joint committee. I notice that some of them have spoken on that matter. The report was two years in the making, with more than 6,000 submissions. That again shows how contentious this issue is and how unhappy people are with the Child Support Act.

Over those two years, there was a total of 15 days of public hearings in every state capital, along with Rockhampton and Launceston; 687 pages of report; a 108‐page summary; and 163 recommendations. Basically, from my reading of it, it said, `Throw out the whole Child Support Act and start again from scratch.' It included key recommendations such as amending the act to ensure that parents share the costs of supporting their children according to their capacity to pay.

It sounds simple and very fair—but what has happened since 1994? Very little. It is fair to say that a few of the joint committee's recommendations are contained in the bill before us, but the vast majority of the 163 recommendations have not seen the light of day. Basically, the inquiry found that the system as it exists is sending non‐custodial parents broke, and making them bitter, angry and potentially homicidal. I cannot begin to guess how much that two‐year inquiry, with its 15 days of hearings around the country, cost the taxpayers—millions of dollars I would suggest. What was the point?

This has been an absolute disgrace. It is government at its most unaccountable and inefficient. The sheer frustration of non‐custodial parents has seen the establishment of lobby groups around the country. One such group in my electorate is the Bathurst based Fair Go Group for non‐custodial parents. On reading this bill, the group wrote to me with the following comment:
As far as I can see these amendments are a bit of a joke, a lot of words that will not alter the Child Support Agency.
They have changed a few words here and there, but that's about it.
I know many backbenchers are getting the same sorts of complaints I have detailed and, like me, would welcome more reforms to iron out problems in the system.

BREAK.PARA: What is the point of a government backbench committee, besides giving that group of members some meaningful work—although I admit there must be some value in revisiting a lot of these areas—when the report is out there? A meaningful report that cost us millions of dollars is sitting there gathering dust. Let us move forward far more rapidly than we have in this area, or we will have tragedies in the community because of it, further exacerbated by the decline of access to legal aid.

I look forward, without too much optimism, to seeing substantial changes during the course of this parliament to assist those paying child support. Those changes mean a substantial attack on implementing the recommendations in the 1994 report. The system, as it stands, is only promoting bitterness and hatred. For the sake of those families, I hope this government, which is supposedly committed to families, brings on more changes sooner rather than later.

If you go back and look at the 6,000 submissions to the inquiry, you will see that most of them talk about the injustice of this act to non‐custodial parents. Today the child support scheme is severely lopsided. It discriminates against non‐custodial parents. It is un‐Australian in that it goes against that most basic principle of a fair go for all. I suggest that at the moment, as it has for years, it is benefiting the lawyers alone. The legal aid cuts are denying access to many people out there, who feel that they cannot break beyond not only the circle of the legal system but also any sort of support network. That is driving them to bitterness and anger.

Also, non‐custodial parents find that their custodial, former partner is using the apprehended violence order system. They are walking down to the police station and having an AVO written out on the most spurious of grounds to keep that non‐custodial parent away from fair and reasonable access to the very children that are part of the equation. That system is being rorted and is being aided and abetted through a frustrated police system that is also understaffed. That is not the area that should be looking after this very technical and very sensitive area of family relations in Australia.

As for the amendment that has been moved by the member for Werriwa (Mr Latham), I see a heap of hypocrisy in it. In fact, to that amendment, where it says `expresses concern at the failure of the Howard government', I would add `and the previous Keating government' to respond to the recommendations of the report of the joint select committee. Of course I will support this amendment. But what the heavens is it doing here now? Why was it not acted upon back in the Keating government's time of office after that report was tabled? That is when action should have begun as a matter of urgency. It was not.

I will support the amendment, so should any other fair‐minded member of this House, given the volume and the loudness of the complaints that are reaching their ears. It has been three years since that report was tabled, yet nothing has happened. Why have we wasted so much time on debating euthanasia in this place? Why was that pushed to such a high order of priority when we have so many issues out there that should take precedence?

Why did the Prime Minister (Mr Howard) allow a private member's bill to get up? He did not have the gumption to move it himself. If he was so concerned about the euthanasia issue, why did he not stand there and introduce the bill himself? Why did we push legislation aside to rush that through when we had so many other important areas that we should have been attacking?

The child support area is one of absolute, paramount importance. Why have we so slavishly tackled the revenue side of things? Why are we not looking at the things that affect the family? While we may be trying to fill in the black hole with bucket loads of money that is being ripped back from PAYE taxpayers, we are not tackling the areas of tax avoidance that we could raise real revenue from.

While we are trying to fill in the black hole, there is another black hole out there—the black hole of abject depression and anger by the non‐custodial parent. That is the black hole that could be a real social disaster in this country if nothing is done very urgently.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Marek, Paul, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —I have already made this House aware of what I see as the inequities in the current child support legislation. But there is always another heartbreaking story about the effect the current legislation is having on the community at this time. I must note that the member for Calare (Mr Andren) got it exactly right when he talked about the non‐custodial parents' payment being calculated weekly like PAYE tax deductions. His statements on that are absolutely right, and I support his speech in that area.

SPEECH.PARA: One heartbreaking story I wish to inform the House about relates to DNA testing. DNA testing is an area that must be addressed to stop malicious claims being made against individuals who may or may not be the father of a particular child. Recently, a case which received national media attention involved the suicide of a father of a loving family when he was informed, out of the blue, by the Child Support Agency that he may be the father of a child from a relationship he had several years ago.

He received this notice from the Child Support Agency stating he owed some $60,000 in back payments. He completely denied the allegations but he was told to pay up or else. He requested a DNA test from the Child Support Agency but was informed if he wanted the test he had to pay for it. He did not have the money and he had no way of proving his case so, in the end, from the pressure and the upset this man endured, he took his own life, leaving a family and of course a lovely wife. I condemn the current operational practices of the Child Support Agency and I urge the minister over the coming months to take up the initiatives put forward by the government child support subcommittee. While I commend this amendment bill because it addresses a number of administrative problems and updates the act's framework, it is only a bandaid.

The real problems in the child support scheme have yet to be addressed by this government, but we are working on them. One of the major reforms in this bill is under chapter 6, headed `Consideration of Child Support in Property and Spousal Maintenance Proceedings'. This is a major step in the right direction and it is not before time that paying parents have their future child support obligations recognised and taken into account by the court in property and spousal maintenance proceedings, irrespective of whether an administrative assessment of child support has been made.

The backbench subcommittee established to investigate the problems in relation to child support has made a number of recommendations that urgently need to be implemented. These have been forwarded to the Minister for Social Security (Senator Newman) and contain what most of us on the committee regard as necessary changes to make the system more equitable for both custodial and non-custodial parents. The Minister for Social Security must act to implement these recommendations as quickly as possible so that the custodial and non-custodial parents can get on with their lives instead of spending hours trying to convince the Child Support Agency, the Family Court or even politicians of the inadequacies in the system.

The Lone Fathers Association is a national organisation which has been representing both male and female non-custodial parents around the country and they have been trying to get changes to the child support system. I have three branches of the Lone Fathers Association in my electorate of Capricornia, which indicates the level of problems my community faces on this issue. At the beginning of this month, the Lone Fathers Association held a national conference on family law here in Canberra, which was a huge success. I attended this convention and was asked to speak to the many people that attended, including DADS, the Child Support Action Group, GRANS, the Family Law Reform Party, Non Custodial Parents, New South Wales Family Law Reform and the national president of Parents Without Partners, plus others as well.

I would like to inform the House that the Lone Fathers Association family law conference passed a number of fair and sensible resolutions on proposed changes to the current Child Support Act. These include custody, access, domestic violence, incest allegations, perjury and grandparents' rights. I will quote these resolutions so that any member of this house can access the recommendations of the Lone Fathers Association through Hansard.
The current Child Support formula should be amended to:
. provide that, in the setting of the formula parameters, the amounts of child support payable are worked out in terms of a flat rate or declining rate on after‐tax income
. reduce the effective marginal rates very substantially (e.g. by at least 50% in the income range $40,000 to $85,000)
. set disregard levels of income for both non-custodial parents and custodial parents at the same level (e.g. at about $10,000 per annum)

. effectively remove the upper limit, currently at two and a half times average weekly earnings, at which no additional payments of child support are able to be made (but only if the other reforms are implemented at the same time)
. in the calculation of child support, provide that the income of a new spouse (including de facto spouse) of a custodial parent be taken into account, at least to some extent, and

. implement the recommendations of the Joint Select Committee on `repairing the child support income base' (Recommendations 142 to 151), in particular, Recommendation 147 that the Child Support Registrar be given the power to make a determination varying a formula assessment for child support, upon request of either parent, where the Registrar considers that the parent obtains financial benefits from his or her employment, business, and investment, or other activities which are not reflected in that parent's taxable income.
There are quite a few other parts to the document. I will move on to the section on grandparents. It reads:

5. Grandparents should be recognised in the Family Law Act as playing, in many cases, a key role in contributing to the welfare of children. The Act should be amended to give grandparents recognition as persons who can issue proceedings, with Section 69C being moved in the Act to become Section 65C.
6. Grandparents who meet more than 5% of the cost of child support should have these costs recognised.
Under the heading `Children', the document reads:

3. The Family Court should, where necessary, enforce the rights of children to access to both parents, grandparents, and significant others, and to receive assistance in their development from all these people.
Under the heading `Perjury', it reads:
8. An offence of perjury should be added to the Family Law Act to enable the Family Court to deal with serious cases such as false accusations of child sexual abuse or domestic violence.

This is one area that should be taken up immediately, because there seems to be so much of this happening at the current time. Under the heading `Allegations of child sexual abuse', the resolution reads:

9. Procedures in investigating allegations of child sexual abuse should be reviewed, with a view to preventing false accusations being made, and assisting an accused person in being heard and receiving natural justice. The Family Law Act should be amended so that the Court is obliged, where an accusation is ultimately found to have been deliberately false, to take that into account in making its decisions.
In relation to domestic violence orders, the resolutions read:

10. The law relating to domestic violence should be reviewed to take into account the denial of natural justice to the accused person involved when orders are made in his/her absence, and stipulating that orders compelling a person to leave or stay away from a family home should only be made on an ex parte basis where essential for the welfare of children and/or spouse.
11. The existence of a domestic violence order made `without admission' or without a determination by a court should not be taken to constitute evidence that any violence has occurred.

The member for Sturt (Mr Pyne) visited my electorate prior to the election and listened to complaints from members of the Lone Fathers Association at the Moranbah branch. I thank him for his involvement and his concern about this emotional subject. I support his earlier statement to the House about not lifting people's expectations too high, so that they expect we can change all the inadequacies in the act in a short space of time. Unfortunately, government does not work like that, but we will continue to hammer away at the door of opportunity.

Earlier in the debate, the member for Werriwa (Mr Latham) made a number of provocative statements about certain members of the government not doing anything about the Child Support Act. But, once again, the member for Werriwa proves that he and his party are all talk and no action. I remind the member for Werriwa that we have achieved better results in the past 12 months than his socialist left party achieved during the 13 years of `Hard Labor' government, even after they had all the recommendations for changes put in their lap by the Price report on the Family Law and Child Support Act.

TALK.START.PARA: —Self‐delusion and self‐denial!

—That is right. Thank you for coming in and supporting my statements. Even 18 months after the report was brought down by the previous government, less than one‐third of the recommendations had come through the House, and most of them were nothing but administrative changes. Where was the member for Werriwa when his government was running the show?

SPEECH.PARA: It is apparent that the member for Werriwa is all wind and no guts. He had the chance to get the ball rolling and address these important issues but, alas, he took the view that he is on the gravy train. Voters in Werriwa should look at his feeble efforts at the next election and should judge his actions on polling day. People affected by the child support scheme deserve better than this cop‐out. We plan to deliver the necessary changes to make this act as equitable as possible. I commend the bill to the House.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hanson, Pauline, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —In rising in the Main Committee today to speak to this amendment to the Child Support Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 1) 1996, I firstly make it clear that I am in agreement with what is proposed. I do not think I would be wrong in saying that nearly every member in this place would confirm that the highest number of complaints they and their offices receive relate to the child support scheme and its myriad of shortcomings.

SPEECH.PARA: The Howard government came to power with a return to family values as part of its platform. It is in the areas of social engineering, which Labor tried to force onto this country, and especially in the areas of family law, that this government—if it is worth its salt—can begin to clean up the mess that the previous government left behind.

One of the most direct examples of the ravages that are being forced on ordinary Australians is the operation of the child support scheme. It is bureaucracy gone mad. They say that from little acorns, great oaks grow. If this government bothers to listen to what is coming from those on the back benches instead of continuing down its born‐to‐rule elitist path, this amendment could be the acorn that will bring equity and fairness to a lot of parents who have had the misfortune of having their marriages break down.

This amendment is merely an attempt at a tweaking of the edges of the monster that is the child support scheme, but it is a start. It puts to rights a couple of areas of poor legislation and practice that will make an unworkable and unwieldy act a little more rational. I support the proposed changes that this amendment brings, but we need to look much deeper into this unjust act and tweak like we have never tweaked before, if we are to obtain justice for all.

As we all know in this place, a government backbench committee has been taking a hard and serious look at the CSS and its lackey the CSA. Assisting some of the members of this committee is a very professional organisation, the members of which have a vital first‐hand interest in the outcomes of this committee's recommendations.

I refer to the Lone Fathers Association of Australia, which has had the opportunity to study the recommendations that the backbench committee is taking to cabinet. I believe it is appropriate that some of the association's comments be read into the public record. In essence, the Lone Fathers Association is in favour of the committee's recommendations, saying that, if adopted by the government, they represent a very substantial improvement on the present child support arrangements.

However, the association has concerns about what it sees as an apparent lack of realisation by the committee that it is the excessively high formula percentages which are the fundamental cause of most of the problems under the present scheme. Reducing the percentages to a reasonable level offers the basic solution to these problems. The association claims that many of the suggestions being made by the committee would simply be unnecessary if the percentages were changed. Although the concept of changing the basis of the current calculation for support payments from gross income to net income seems, on the surface, to have merit by itself, this will not solve the problems faced by many non‐custodial parents.

The association claims that it will also be necessary to change the structure and level of the percentages, based on a proper judgment about the payments which would be fair at each level of disposable income. In its study into the recommendations, from which I quote, the association says:

Changing to a calculation based on net income will tend to be an improvement, because it will, other things being equal, result in much better equity between different levels of income where a flat percentage rate applies. However, a single flat percentage rate, even on an after‐tax basis, is far from being the best and fairest arrangement.
For a fairer and better arrangement, several different percentages will be needed, applying to different income ranges.

This is referring to the `sliding scale' concept referred to by the committee. Before I go further into the response from the Lone Fathers Association, I think that it must be made clear that most non‐custodial parents are concerned for their children's futures and are willing to contribute financially to those futures.

What has to be taken out of the child support scheme is the unfairness that applies in so many cases, with its replacement by a system that is based not on the remnants of the rampant feminism of the past couple of decades but on a just and equitable situation for both parents. The current system, in fact, often works to the detriment of the custodial parent. It is so draconian that in many cases the non-custodial parent is forced to opt for the dole rather than try to live on the pittance that is left after the CSA is finished with them.

This is self‐defeating, in that it goes dead against the original intent of this legislation—to remove the financial load of child support from the taxpayers' shoulders and place it onto the parents. It is artificially increasing our unemployment payments to those parents who take the dole option, not to mention the loss to national productivity of these otherwise eminently employable people.

In another area, the current scheme totally removes the incentive for non‐custodial parents to earn overtime or other penalty payments, in that these are all taken into account when calculating the percentage of payment. Non‐custodial parents who remarry often find it absolutely necessary to earn money from a second job or overtime in their main job, simply to support the second family, but the disincentives of the scheme see the CSA and the custodial parent grabbing an excessive share of this extra money.

Again the Lone Fathers Association has picked up problems with excluding second incomes and overtime from the CSS percentages, in that it discriminates against different employment structures and increases, not decreases, the bureaucratic nightmare that is the child support scheme. According to the association:

The correct solution to the problem is to alter the structure of formula percentages to allow for the fact that income tax rates are progressive with income. This means setting child support percentages as a flat rate or declining rate on after-tax income.
As to the recommendation of the introduction of a sliding scale of child support according to a child's age, the Lone Fathers agree that:

. . . while fine tuning of the system is perhaps desirable in principle, it could tend to distract attention from the more important issues—the need for a reduction in the overall formula percentages.

The association quite wisely points out that such an amendment to the scheme would add significantly to the cost of administration of the Child Support Agency—and this at a time when the CSA is already facing serious difficulties with proposed cutbacks in staff numbers. This will mean more trouble for the government, not less.

Access for non‐custodial parents is also an issue that the committee has looked at, with a recommendation that the paying parent be reimbursed through child support payments for those periods when he or she has access to the child—in other words, the suspension of child support payments when children are on access visits with their non‐custodial parent. The association agrees that this is a good idea, a proposal that might remove the attraction for some custodial parents to remove themselves and the children to a great distance from the non‐custodial parent just in order to make access difficult. Not only that, but also it is pure logic that when the custodial parent is not financially supporting the children during access times, it does not make sense that the non‐custodial parent should continue to pay support payments as well as being responsible for the day‐to‐day support of the children while they are in his or her control.

In addressing the committee's recommendations that a cap be placed on child support to genuinely reflect the actual cost of maintaining a child and that more consideration be given for second families to ensure across‐the‐board equity for the children of both marriages, the Lone Fathers Association is very scathing about the formula upon which current percentages are based. They describe the academic research done by Espenshade in the United States and Lee in Australia as:
. . . arbitrary, subjective, unrealistic and seriously misleading assumptions. As far as assessing the costs of raising children are concerned, the results of those studies are essentially nonsense.
They go on to say:

Fundamentally, what is needed is not a formula based on the type of nonsense data produced by Espenshade and Lee, but a more commonsense and realistic appreciation of the actual circumstances of separated families and, in particular, the incentives to earn income. In that formula, amounts of child support payable could essentially be limited to a reasonable amount by the setting of appropriate formula percentages.

In so far as the equity of second families and the children of those second families are concerned, it is vital that any formula used to calculate child support ensures equity for all. Children of subsequent marriages are as equally entitled to a fair share of the non‐custodial parent's income as are the children of the original marriage.
On this matter, the Lone Fathers say:

To implement the Espenshade/Lee approach consistently it would be necessary to grant all children, whether from first or subsequent families, an approximately equal share of the non‐custodial parent's income along similar lines to the proposal made by Justice Kay and reported in the 1991 report of the Child Support Evaluation Advisory Committee.

Fundamentally, what is needed is not a formula based on the type of nonsense data produced by Espenshade and Lee, but a commonsense and realistic appreciation of the actual circumstances of separated families and, in particular, the incentives to earn income. In that formula there would be much more attention paid to proper equity between the children of the first and subsequent marriages.

In closing, what we have inherited here with the child support scheme and the Child Support Agency is, according to the body that arguably has more working knowledge of the scheme and a vital self‐interest in it, the worst kind of a camel which we all know is a horse designed by a committee. The tweaking at the edges that this amendment offers can, if this government has the guts and the gumption to take it head‐on, eventually bring proper and true social justice to a significant number of real Australians out there who are suffering unnecessarily. I commend the amendment but, on behalf of a lot of fathers and mothers in my electorate, make a plea to the government to undertake, as a matter of the highest priority, a full and exhaustive review of this quagmire of an act.
Debate (on motion by Mr Bradford) adjourned.

PROCTEXT.PARA: The following answers to questions were circulated:

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Mossfield, Frank, MP

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Attorney-General and Minister for Justice, upon notice, on 5 February 1997.

QUESTION.PARA: Are there proposals to (a) amend legislation to ensure that court orders setting in place parental access to children can be enforced, (b) enable the enforcement of access orders when one of the estranged parents moves children within a State or interstate and (c) provide penalties when one of the estranged parents continues to breach access orders.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Williams, Daryl, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (a) Since June 1996 the Family Law Act 1975 no longer provides for access by parents to their children. Rather, the Family Law Reform Act 1995 amended the Act in recognition that it is the right of children to have contact with their parents, provided that contact is in the children's best interests. Instead of custody, guardianship and access orders, the Family Court now makes parenting orders, including residence, contact and specific issues orders. Transitional provisions ensure that access orders in effect at the commencement of the Reform Act continue to have effect, and are treated as if they were contact orders made under the new legislation.

In considering issues such as enforcement of Family Court orders, it is important to recognise the fundamental change of approach that the amendments embody, and the new emphasis on reaching flexible and tailored arrangements under which both parents can continue to share their parental responsibilities after separation, unless this is not in the children's best interests.

The issues relating to enforcement of contact orders were considered by the Australian Law Reform Commission in its 1995 report "For the Sake of the Kids". That report recognised that lack of compliance is not a simple or isolated issue, and that a non-punitive approach may better serve the aim of facilitating contact in many cases. The Commission also recommended that the best interests of the children should be the paramount consideration in any approach to enforcement of orders.

The report made a number of recommendations in relation to complex contact cases in the Family Court, including some relating to the legislative regime for dealing with breaches of contact orders. The report is currently under consideration.

(b) A contact order made by the Family Court remains enforceable unless and until it is varied, suspended, discharged or set aside. Action may be taken against a person who moves children within a State or interstate without agreement from the other parent or the Court, and thereby prevents compliance with a contact order. The question of enforcement of contact orders where a parent moved children within a State or interstate was not considered separately by the Law Reform Commission. There are no proposals under consideration to treat enforcement of contact orders where the parents live a significant distance apart differently from other contact orders.

(c) The Family Law Act 1975 provides a range of orders that may be made by the Court when it is satisfied that a person has, without reasonable excuse, contravened an order, including a contact order.
The orders that may be made by the court include:

a sentence of imprisonment for a period of 12 months or less, a fine, requiring the person to enter into a recognizance, a contact order, having regard to the deprivation of contact resulting from the contravention.
Pursuant to arrangements with all States and Territories except New South Wales, the Court can also make a community service order.

The Australian Law Refom Commission recommended that the Court's discretion as to the appropriate penalty should be maintained, but that the Court should give greater consideration to the circumstances where community service orders and periodic detention may be appropriate. The Commission further recommended that imprisonment should continue to be a sanction of last resort only.

The Family Law Council is currently collecting data on penalties imposed by the Family Court. Once sufficient data has been collected and analysed, the Council will report to me on the issues arising from the Council's analysis of the data.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Campbell, Graeme, MP

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Resources and Energy, upon notice, on 4 March 1997:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Is the Minister able to say whether statutory declaration, made by members of the crew of the Griffin Venture state that purge pipes were not properly earthed.
(2) Would it have been impossible to drill near Ningaloo Reef for many years if the Griffin Venture had exploded.

(3 Is the Minister able to say whether (a) a similar breach of safety standards on the Griffin Venture occurred 19 months earlier (b) BHP at that time reported that measures had been taken to ensure safety breaches would not re-occur and (c) a dangerous freeing incident occurred on the Jabiru Venture on 23 March 1996; if so, (d) does the Minister have confidence in BHP's attitude to safety matters.
(4) Is the Minister able to say whether the report on the Griffin Venture by Dr Barrell acknowledges that pipes were not earthed properly and therefore there was potential for ignition.
(5) Is the Minister able to say how Dr Barrell concluded that the Griffin Venture was never in jeopardy.

(6) Did Mr T Visscher request on 19 April 1996 a list of documents supplied to Dr Barrell by the Department of Primary Industries and Energy (DPIE); if so was the list provided on 21 May 1996; if so, why.
(7) Was the transcript of the master's evidence made available to Dr Barrell but not that of Mr Visscher; if so, why.
(8) Is the Minister able to say whether the master of the Jabiru Venture cleaned the tanks by purging them with sea water en route to Singapore.
(9) Had Dr Barrell concluded his report before DPIE had provided its list of questions.
(10) Was additional evidence from Mr Visscher considered.
(11) What documents were provided (a) to Dr Barrell and
(b) by Mr Visscher.
(12) (a) Was Mr Visscher's submission provided to Dr Barrell; if not, why not.
(13) Did Mr Visscher fax DPIE on 25 May 1996 a list with 339 potentially relevant documents.

(14) Was Mr Visscher advised on 30 May 1996 that the (a) DPIE Safety Officer was unaware of the existence of the majority of the documents on Mr Visscher's list and (b) report had been finalised and Dr Barrell had returned to England.
(15) Did Dr Barrell not consider all relevant documents; if not, is his report satisfactory.
(16) Is the Minister able to say where the master of the Griffin Venture on 29 May 1994 is now employed.
(17) Will the Minister initiate a parliamentary inquiry into either the safety culture of BHP or the incidents referred to in this question.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Anderson, John, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Resources and Energy has provided the following answer to the honourable member's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Yes. The statutory declarations state that purge pipes were not properly earthed.
(2) No. In the completely hypothetical instance that the Griffin Venture had exploded on 29 May 1994, it is highly improbable that there would have been any impact on the Ningaloo Reef whatsoever

PARA.TAB: Ningaloo Reef is 68 km to the south west of the Griffin Venture 's location;
the prevailing trade winds are from the south east, blowing therefore towards the north west away from the coast, at 15-20 knots;
the current is basically parallel to the coast at the Griffin Venture site;

oil spill response computer modelling of a worst case scenario of the 29 May 1994 incident, with all the oil on board the facility entering the sea, indicated that the oil would have been carried in a westerly direction, away from the coast;

ANSWER.PARA: Griffin crude oil is a very light, highly volatile oil with a high dispersion rate—upwards of 70% would evaporate and disperse within nine hours of being spilt in the 250 C water of the area. Wave action would also act to break up the remaining heavy ends.

PARA.TAB: the Ningaloo Reef would therefore not have been at risk.

ANSWER.PARA: (3) (a) The chronology of the BHPP safety related incidents is

PARA.TAB: 29 May 1994—Griffin Venture gas-freeing incident
3 January 1996 Griffin Venture valve explosion and gas release
23 March Jabiru Venture gas freeing incident

ANSWER.PARA: (3) (b) Yes
(3) (c) There was a breakdown in safety procedures on the BHPP facility Jabiru Venture on 23 March 1996 which involved gas freeing.
(3) (d) Yes. The Government now does have confidence in BHPP's attitude to safety matters because of

PARA.TAB: Dr Barrell's recognition of the program to upgrade BHPP's safety arrangements that the company had already commenced at the time of his review;
the organisation's very positive response to the recommendations of Dr Barrell's report;

the company's subsequent very positive commitment to upgrading its offshore safety managment arrangements, improving the safety culture of its employees and the quality and extent of communication between management and the offshore employees; and
its demonstration to the Government through a program of regular formal assessments its continued commitment to progress to a standard of world's best safety practice.

ANSWER.PARA: However, the Government realises that changing the safety culture of the staff of an organisation cannot be done overnight

PARA.TAB: the Government intends to continue with its safety assessments in the immediate future;
additionally, the Government has arranged for Dr Barrell to further review the safety arrangements of the company in April/May/June of this year.

ANSWER.PARA: These actions are intended as positive measures to reinforce the awareness of the BHPP workforce of the need for strict compliance with the safety standards of the organisation.

(4) (a) Dr Barrell concluded that "Mr Visscher's allegations that the purge pipes were not adequately earthed is also subject to conflicting evidence. In my opinion, however, on the balance of probabilities, the pipes were probably not earthed properly ".

(4) (b) However, Dr Barrell did not accept that this automatically meant that a source of ignition would have resulted had the cargo tanks been purged through the pipes as they were set up on the day. Dr Barrell's view, conveyed to Departmental officials, was

PARA.TAB: in his expert opinion, there was no guarantee that a source of ignition (hot spots or electrostatic sparks) would have resulted from the gas passing through the purge pipe;

he also felt that whether or not an ignition source would have resulted could never be established after the fact—that no laboratory test could duplicate the actual conditions of gas mixture, gas flow rates, temperature, humidity and purge pipe friction sources actually extant on the Griffin Venture on 29 May 1994;

in his opinion, then, it was therefore impossible to establish whether in fact a source of ignition would have resulted had the purge pipes been actually used on 29 May 1994, but it certainly was possible that a source of ignition could have been created by improper assembly and earthing.

ANSWER.PARA: In point of fact, of course, the purge pipes were never actually used during the events of 29 May 1994.

(5) Dr Barrell found that "the Griffin Venture was not placed in jeopardy, in that a flammable concentration of hydrocarbon vapour in air was never present in the cargo tank" . He further stated that "in terms of preventing a cargo tank explosion, the most important safeguard is to ensure that the atmosphere in the tank never reaches a flammable range. Exclusion of sources of ignition is a second line of defence."
In arriving at his conclusion, Dr Barrell took into consideration the following:

PARA.TAB: that while there is hotly disputed and conflicting evidence as to what the intent of the various parties was in regard to introducing air into the cargo tank whilst it still contained high concentrations of hydrocarbon vapour, the undisputed fact is that air was not introduced into the cargo tank at that time. Therefore, a highly volatile gas mixture—with the specific percentages of hydrocarbon vapour and oxygen required to form an explosive combination—was never actually created in the cargo tank during the operation;
similarly, that the unearthed purge pipes, with the possibility of a source of ignition being created if gas was purged through them, were never actually used to purge gas during the operation;

therefore, at no time on 29 May 1994 did the elements required to cause an explosion—hydrocarbon vapour and oxygen combined together in proportions which created an explosive mixture and a source of ignition—ever actually exist;
therefore, at no time during the events of 29 May 1996, as they actually occurred, was the Griffin Venture ever in danger of exploding, and therefore at no time was the facility actually in jeopardy.

ANSWER.PARA: (6) (a) Yes. On 19 April 1996, Mr Visscher queried DPIE as to what documents were on file relevant to the 1994 Griffin Venture gas freeing incident. DPIE agreed to supply Mr Visscher with a list of the documents that they had on hand in order that Mr Visscher could then compare that list with his own collection of documents. Mr Visscher offered to make available to DPIE any relevant documents in his own collection that DPIE required.

(6) (b) Yes. Dr Barrell considered the 1994 Griffin Venture gas freeing incident—including the earthing configuration of the purge pipes and other issues—in the first weeks in his review after examining relevant documents

PARA.TAB: he formed his views after speaking to Mr Visscher and other relevant persons, interviewing BHPP personnel, from his own expert knowledge, his many years of relevant experience, and his consideration of the large amount of written and verbal evidence available to him;

his conclusions either already supported Mr Visscher's assertions regarding the earthing of the purge pipes and the improper use of gas-freeing and gas detection procedures, or concerned the state of mind of the Master of the Griffin Venture on 29 May 1996—which Dr Barrel considered could in no way be determined two years later;
only in the matter of the Griffin Venture being placed in jeopardy did he disagree with Mr Visscher, and he reached his conclusion on this issue based on his own expert knowledge;

he therefore considered that accessing any further documents regarding the 1994 incident would be unnecessary. Dr Barrell felt that his time would be far better spent in complying with the specific Terms of Reference of his review and, in particular, developing a strategy which ensured the future safety of all personnel on BHP Petroleum's facilities;

however, DPIE had promised to provide the list to Mr Visscher, and an attempt was made to list the relevant documents on the official files when time allowed. The responsible officers were fully involved in assisting Dr Barrell and on other matters until 21 May 1996.

ANSWER.PARA: (7) No. Dr Barrell had complete access to all the files of DPIE and the WA and NT regulators, including both Mr Visscher's transcript of evidence as well as that of the Master.
(8) It is understood that, during transit to Singapore in 1991, the Jabiru Venture washed heavy formation sand deposits from some of its tanks

PARA.TAB: prior to the facility's disconnecting from the riser, all traces of hydrocarbons had been thoroughly washed and stripped to an offtake tanker in lieu of a shore sludge storage installation in accordance with the International Safety Guide for Oil Tankers and Terminals recommendations. The standard of tank cleanliness complied with the Marine Pollution Convention (MARPOL) requirements;

a final bottom wash was carried out to remove heavy formation sand deposits. These washings were pumped overboard in compliance with MARPOL regulations. The vessel remained over 50 nautical miles south of Lombok Strait approaches until such washing was completed;

during these washings, steady stream of dark colored sand mixed with wash water was discharged through the stern manifold. This may have led to a belief that the washings contained oil residues, which they did not.

ANSWER.PARA: (9) No

(10) Yes. Dr Barrell viewed Mr Visscher's video presentation and read the transcript of the video. He also considered Mr Visscher's comments on some of the conclusions and evidence in relation to the various inquiries. He also examined the list of documents supplied by Mr Visscher on 25 May 1996 to see if there was any material contained therein that would affect his views. He concluded that his findings in regard to the 1994 Griffin Venture gas freeing incident would not be changed by consideration of the documents listed by Mr Visscher.

11 (a) Dr Barrell was provided with access to all relevant material on the DPIE, NT and WA regulator's files. A list of relevant material contained on the DPIE files, more comprehensive than that provided to Mr Visscher on 25 May 1996, is attached.

(b) Additional material supplied by Mr Visscher to DPIE and other sources was provided to Dr Barrell, and forms part of the above list. Mr Visscher's listing of 339 documents was provided to Dr Barrell, though many of the individual documents listed were not.

(12) Yes. This material was available to Dr Barrell in the files of the WA regulator, the Designated Authority responsible for the Griffin Venture , when he visited them in May 1996. By this time, he had already spoken to Mr Visscher personally, viewed his video presentation, read the various official reports, interviewed Griffin Venture crew members and spoken to expert AMSA personnel

PARA.TAB: Mr Visscher's submission had already been examined in detail by the joint WA/AMSA review in March 1995, and taken into account when formulating that report;
there was no additional information in this submission that Dr Barrell had not already considered in other forms;

he had already come to conclusions which agreed with Mr Visscher in two out of his four concerns. Consideration of the original submission presented to the WA/AMSA review was unlikely to have new material which would alter his conclusions in regard to the remaining two issues;
the main focus of his review was the current BHPP safety management arrangements;
in view of these factors, Dr Barrell chose not to read the 300-odd pages of Mr Visscher's submission.

ANSWER.PARA: (13) Mr Visscher faxed a list of 339 documents to DPIE on 25 May 1996. The relevance of many of these documents is highly questionable.
(14) (a) Yes. Mr Visscher was advised that the DPIE officer was not aware of many of the documents on Mr Visscher's list, including

PARA.TAB: many of the 36 faxes from Mr Visscher to Senators Margetts, WA Greens, Mr John Prescott, CEO BHP, Senator Scott, WA Greens, and a number of other persons;

the majority of the 116 letters, memos, reports, log excerpts, and personal faxes sent to Mr Visscher from a variety of sources such as BHPP, the WA regulator, various politicians, somebody named "Brian", and other unknown persons;

the majority of the 149 pieces of correspondence from Mr Visscher to others about attending meetings, staying on leave and extending leave, updating TV commentators, informing politicians, advising about media releases, copying other faxes and correspondence to other people, conveying thanks, proposing meetings, making presentations, etc, etc;

ANSWER.PARA: The DPIE officer was certainly aware, however, of the essential reports, interview statements, statutory declarations, comments on reports, etc, relevant to Dr Barrell's review of BHPP's safety management arrangements.
(14) (b) Yes
(15) (a) Yes. Dr Barrell considered all the documents necessary to meet the requirements of his Terms of Reference and the subsequent direction from the Minister for Resources and Energy

PARA.TAB: Dr Barrell's Terms of Reference called for him to review BHPP's safety management arrangements relating to the Griffin Venture safety incident of 3 January 1996, and provide advice on whether those arrangements were satisfactory and whether there were any other relevant measures which could improve the safety performance of BHPP's offshore facilities;

he was instructed by the Minister for Resources and Energy to take into account all other BHPP safety related incidents, including the 1994 Griffin Venture and the 23 March 1996 Jabiru Venture gas freeing incidents, when making his determinations and writing his report.

Dr Barrell did so. In conducting his review according to his Terms of Reference and his Ministerial instructions, Dr Barrell considered an extensive range of documents ranging from official reports to additional evidence supplied by Mr Visscher. He talked to Mr Visscher himself, he viewed his video presentation and read through the video transcript. He interviewed employees on the Griffin Venture and other BHPP facilities, and BHPP management in Melbourne, Dampier and Darwin. He consulted the WA and NT regulators and AMSA.

ANSWER.PARA: Dr Barrell more than adequately familiarised himself with the facts and circumstances surrounding the various BHPP safety incidents—including that of the gas freeing on Griffin Venture on 29 May 1994. He conducted his review according to his Terms of Reference and his instructions.

(b) Dr Barrell's report is satisfactory. Dr Barrell produced a report which resulted in BHPP publicly recognising that it had deficiencies in its offshore safety managment arrangements and committing $36 million dollars to a program to rectify those deficiencies—a program which it is now well on the way to completing. This was a highly satisfactory outcome from the Government's point of view.

PARA.TAB: Dr Barrell's review was not established to try to determine whether every allegation made by Mr Visscher about the May 1994 events could be substantiated. Dr Barrell's main job was to ensure that the personnel working on BHPP's facilities are not put at undue risk—now or in the future.

ANSWER.PARA: (16) It is understood that he is employed by BHPP as a Master on the Challis Venture .

(17) No. The Government has already been involved in a joint inquiry with the WA Government into the events of the 1994 Griffin Venture gas freeing incident. It has commissioned a very thorough review by Dr Barrell of the safety management arrangements of BHPP—a review which has resulted in the company expending very considerable energy and physical and financial resources examining and improving its arrangements

PARA.TAB: BHPP has a comprehensive plan in place to brings its safety management arrangements to the standard of world best practice. It is paying particular attention to improving the safety culture of its offshore employees and the quality of communications between management and the offshore staff;

the Government has been regularly assessing the performance of BHPP in implementing the comprehensive safety upgrade program to which it has committed itself, and is satisfied with its progress so far. This assessment program will continue for as long as is necessary;

the Government has arranged to have Dr Barrell review, in April/May of this year, the pro gress which BHPP has made in improving its safety managment arrangements in line with the recommendations of his report.

ANSWER.PARA: The Government sees no reason to waste the taxpayers money and the valuable energy and time of this Parliament by initiating a Parliamentary inquiry.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Department of Industry, Science and Tourism: Paper Supplies

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Ferguson, Laurie, MP

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Industry, Science and Tourism, upon notice, on 5 March 1997:

QUESTION.PARA: Have samples of the paper products purchased by the Minister's Department been examined by the Australian Government Analytical Laboratories or private sector alternatives to establish or verify their Australian fibre content.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Moore, John, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: No. Samples of the paper products purchased by my Department have not been examined by the Australian Government Analytical Laboratories or private sector alternatives to establish or verify their Australian fibre content.

I am advised that the majority of paper used by my Department is copy paper which is purchased through a government contract. These products are wholly manufactured in Australia from fibres sourced from Australian plantations and regrowth forests.
